Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that this was a superb film which captures the feel of growing up in the ghetto in an excellent manner. To that effect there is quite a bit of profanity and some violence which serves to make it even more compelling and realistic. That being said I definitely recommend this movie to all viewers interested in a film of this type.

reviews.review_title: powerful, dated but not in the wrong places, Fishburne and Cube and Gooding too
reviews.content: Boyz N the Hood sparked many films in that "hood" form (think Menace II Society, South Central, Singleton's own Poetic Justice and later Juice), but the film took inspiration from the real master of them all: Do the Right Thing. Singleton saw that film and immediately started on the script for his own tale of inner-city youth encased in problems of racial oppression, sexual politics and other forms of discrimination and, of course, the gang violence. Though certain parts have not aged especially well, the core of the film, about the relationship between a son and father, as well as how to operate in a neighborhood where violence is around every corner, does hold up and resonates well.It starts and has its first half hour spent (wisely) in 1984, when young Tre gets in a fight at school and his mother (Angela Basset, only in three scenes but essential to the story) takes him to live with his father (Fishburne, maybe his best/subtlest performance), who can "teach him how to be a man" as she puts it more than once. And lo and behold, he can as he is a responsible parent with his own business; indeed one can imagine if they were living in the suburbs or elsewhere in a less hazardous area, they'd be a reasonably normal unit. But right away we see the trouble the night Tre moves in: a home invader comes in, Furious fires some shots to scare him off, and the cops show and do nothing (we also get the first moment of the racist *black* cop, who shows up in one of the most memorable scenes in the picture).Then cut ahead to seven years later - Tre's friend Doughboy gets sent to juvenile detention for a crime that's only hinted at, but we can guess the severity - and now it's high school years. In some ways, the majority of this picture still takes from a typical 'youth' picture: the concerns are boys chasing girls, some girls going after boys, and, as pertinent to some youth movies, gang violence. For example, could one see the altercation that sets up much of the trouble in the last act be seen in a 50's B-movie? Probably. Certainly some of the melodrama could be akin to something far removed from this on the surface like Rebel Without a Cause. And certainly again it's also about what effect, or lack thereof, parents have on their children in such an environment.Although at one point Singleton nearly stops the movie for a speech on gentrification - more distracting not so much for the speech but how immediately people gather around to listen and respond, which feels the most "screenwriter-y" of the movie - most of what he is showing really works: urban alienation and the sense that things won't get better (i.e. Doughboy's brother); the dangers of urban youth having children at a young age (lack of sex education is hinted at); and, of course, the lack of any real authority or leadership from those who "Serve and Protect." When it comes to the 'hood' of the film, it's often the opposite.The scene with the racist black cop is striking for how Singleton takes what could be just a very one-dimensional character - we don't really know his name - and fills him with real conflict. The self-hating black man is a figure that probably wasn't seen in many films, certainly set in urban decay, and it's this that actually pushes Tre to the limit (at first, anyway, to a scene later parodied especially in the Wayans' Don't Be a Menace where he punches at air). What to make of someone who is not only not helping but on the opposite end is actively going out of his way to oppress his own people? Is this constructive? Will this get people to change? More like a self-fulfilling prophecy, actually.Some of the music choices, not the songs so much as the score, hasn't aged well at all - it's like Badalamenti's music for Twin Peaks but much less engrossing. And a few moments in the last act stand out as being very melodramatic; I have to say just a few though as the moment where a mother discovers her son is dead is still a tremendous gut punch (notice how little Singleton cuts away in this scene, and how Cube is trying to remain the strong one in the scene - only near the end do we see him get emotional). Furious has lived through this world, gone through his own troubles, and still has to remain strong for his on. But how far can he go for someone who he sees now as a 'grown man'? Is he still just a boy lost in this world? Gooding plays Tre as a man who is strong and confident, but because he is a good person it's trouble in another way: how can you act as a good man in a world that doesn't allow you to be so? Where having a gun is preferable to not having one? For all of the little things and scenes that don't quite work today in the film, there's nevertheless so much resonance and logic to the storytelling that it's hard to not get wrapped up in it. I might look to 'Menace' as being a little better far as filmmaking goes, but this was the gold standard for many years for a reason or two: Singleton takes another step from what Spike Lee started and transposes it into trying to speak about the bigger picture as far as how men treat women in this world, how men treat one another, and what options are there be you decent or a thug (sometimes, in the case of Doughboy, that awful grey area, where you don't know how the f*** to feel).

reviews.review_title: Boyz n the hood aren't always hard
reviews.content: The men in Boyz N The Hood are reaching that awkward point where you're not a boy, but not quite a man. Dealing with this is hard, but I can't begin to imagine how hard it is when you live in the hood with constant fear of violence, racism, and gang trouble becoming deadly. I live in a small suburban town, almost nothing happens where I live and I'm thankful. It is almost strictly a white town. Racial segregation is common in most neighborhoods, and actor Laurence Fishburne speaks about that in the middle of the film.The movie begins by showing us ten year old Tré Styles who gets in trouble at school, resulting in a suspension. Tré and his other Reva (Bassett) made an agreement that if he got in any more trouble he would be sent to live with his stern father Jason, nicknamed Furious (Fishburne).After half an hour of seeing the young life of the boy, the film fast forwards seven years later. Tré (Gooding Jr.), now seventeen, is trying to pressure his girlfriend into marriage, at the same time juggling school and keeping up with his hoodlum pal Darren, nicknamed Doughboy (Cube) and his football playing brother Ricky (Chestnut). All three boys struggle to live their own lives in a town filled with hatred and gang violence.The main thing the film wants to show is that a strong father figure is very important in a young black man's life. Woman can raise them, but a everybody needs a man for a sense of direction and guidance in difficult times. The character that has the best family is Tré, and it shows that it really has an affect on him. At the end of the film, Furious guides him away from possible danger that very well could've saved his life. The audience always asks "What would've happen if Doughboy had Tré's father? Would the outcome change?" The answer is most definitely.Director John Singleton has made a film that not only depicts realism of gangs without glorifying it in any way, but has a way of treating his characters like true human beings with hopes and dreams. The color of their skin doesn't matter. Just like in Baby Boy, his film that concluded his hood trilogy ten years after this one, he has made a film showcasing blacks outside of their racial stereotype.Besides excellent camera-work and writing, we see the roles that lead Cuba Gooding Jr. and Ice Cube to have many more movie roles. Cuba is at his best in this, and Ice Cube does very well with the drama based script. Seeing him in Barbershop and Friday, I was skeptical if he would play a drama role with goofiness or true sincerity. The outcome was more than I had ever expected, and leads me to question why Cube doesn't spend more time in the drama field of film.Boyz N The Hood is truly a masterpiece in the world of film. Scene after scene is breathtaking and emotional. It is so well acted and so well filmed it almost comes off as a documentary. And above all, everything in the film, every character, moment, line, and event is all crafted so well it's like reality. The scary part is, it's someone's.Starring: Cuba Gooding Jr., Ice Cube, Morris Chestnut, and Laurence Fishburne. Directed by: John Singleton.

reviews.review_title: Gripping, never let's go of the audience
reviews.content: I always thought that such films that were named like Boyz N the Hood, Hustle and Flow, and Menace 2 Society, normally titles like that are not promising to a good movie. But I have seen Hustle and Flow and Menace 2 Society which were both really good movies surprisingly and one movie that everyone recommends to me was Boyz N the Hood and just praising it, so I finally sat down and watched it the other day and this movie just got to me. This is one of the better acted movies with stories of the ghetto and the thing that I loved about this film was that it had a good strong positive message to never let go of your dreams and don't let stupid people get you down. I was really impressed mainly with the performances in this movie, who didn't have a great performance in this movie? But I think it was Lawerence Fishbourne and Cuba Gooding, Jr. that really steal the show and tell the story so well.Tre is having a hard time in the city where he and his mother live, he gets in trouble at school and she sends him to live with his dad, Furious Styles for the summer to teach him how to be a man. Tre grows up, comes back for a summer, and lives with his dad, seeing old friends and reconnecting with an old flame, one problem, this is all happening in South Central where the shootings are frequent, drugs are being done 24/7, and you have a 98% chance of being a looser that will probably die. He and his two best friends learn how to deal with the possibility of being killed or doing something they can never take back.Boyz N the Hood is a powerful movie that is very impressive, especially for a film that was made under a seven million dollar budget. I would recommend this movie, it is a bit violent and the swearing is persistent, but this is a film about the ghetto. But I felt like this film had a positive message that really made me smile and just kept rooting for these poor boys who had no say in their lives and just had to do the best the could to make it out of these deadly situations where they could die before even making it into an adult life. I really liked Boyz N the Hood, it's a good strong movie that will remind you to hold onto your dreams and don't let anyone get you down.8/10

reviews.content: Such a film is a masterpiece of realism and cynicism because realism is always cynical in front of evil, because that sadism here aims at showing the horror of black ghettos or urban projects in Los Angeles. It illustrates the fact that the vast majority of black murderers kill black victims. It is in fact the same thing as for white murderers and white victims. Who is the copy cat? Or is it a rule that you murder one of your own? In other words crime is not racist, not even racial, in its vast majority. It is nothing but the result of a social, cultural, ideological, economic and political situation that nurtures it. But the film provides absolutely no answer about that social situation. Cynical black cops who can only repress, even the innocent, when they do something at all, especially when that innocent is black, though most of the time these cops do nothing as for protecting the black community against the crime it feeds and raises in its own heart like a pet in a home. There is no hope except escape, go away as far as possible to free ourselves from the white plot that locks blacks together to produce a self-destructive boiling pot of a community, not even seeing it may be a time bomb that could harm the whole society when it explodes. It only wants to impress the audience with a fate, a fatality and create in its audience a feeling, emotion of total rejection based on disgust, maybe even hatred. But there is no hope anywhere in that film. No hope whatsoever.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 8 Saint Denis, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID

Touching, well-made drama about life in the dangerous and violent ghetto of South Central Los Angeles. Fishburne is a divorced father who's dedicated to living a legitimate life, but more importantly steering his impressionable young son (Gooding) away from the violence and ignorance of his turbulent surroundings. Well-crafted and insightful story is gripping, powerfully acted, and at times shockingly emotional. The occasionally graphic and profane subject matter can be off-putting at times, but it's vividly realized by director Singleton making this a revealing look at life in the hood. ***

The unexepected tragedy in the end left my mouth wide open.  It also left me wondering how someone could do something so horrible and not have any remorse?  This kind of thing does go on in real life and it is scary.  In other words, a good film from John Singleton who also directed Higher Learning and Shaft (2000). 5/5

reviews.review_title: Very well made and packed with real world problems...and rather hard to watch because of this.
reviews.content: "Boyz n the Hood" is a film that isn't pleasant viewing....it's hard, sad and will likely leave you feeling like you could use a Kleenex. But this does not mean it's a bad film nor one you should avoid. After all, in a hellish environment like South Central LA in 1991, it's hard to make the story fun! But it is important to talk about this...and the film raises our awareness of the problems facing folks living there.The story is about a group of friends who grew up in a horrible neighborhood due to all the violence and drugs. It's told from the viewpoint of Tre (Cuba Gooding Jr.) and you see the way the neighborhood and violence practically destroy him...and does lead to the deaths of some of his friends. In many ways, it's like watching a slow-motion car crash...you know something BAD is going to happen but it's inevitable as well.The film is tough to watch...violence, crude and not exactly mainstream. But this is why I respect the film so much...it's NOT a typical story of black America that you see on TV...it's rough, unrelenting and sad...at least for these poor folks. Well worth seeing and with some excellent acting performances and a heart-wrenching script.

reviews.review_title: Well-made, great for the right audience.
reviews.content: Sitting down to watch Boyz 'N the Hood right now feels fitting. I appreciate what it has to say about the struggles of the black community and gentrification. In fact, I'd be lying if I didn't say that I was a bit choked up when Laurence Fishburne goes on his rant. I wish there was more of that in the film. Sadly, it felt like the rest of the movie was a fairly by-the-numbers story about young people growing up in a dangerous community with a lot of bad influences. Coming-of-age is already a genre that I don't typically enjoy, and adding in the depressing nature of this particular film, I had a tough time with it. Admittedly, I was emotionally invested in the journey of the characters, and I shed a few tears at one point when tragedy struck. Yet I saw it coming. Every beat of this movie felt like something I've seen before in other films, so it was extremely predictable. Many of those movies might have been drawing inspiration from this one, but I just happen to be in a place now where this all seemed rote. I guess at this point I'm looking for a more unique or nuanced approach to these topics, or even films that shine a light on how we can move forward rather than the pessimistic note we are left with here. I can't deny that Boyz 'N the Hood is a well-made movie, and I imagine if I saw it back in the early 90s when I was a teen it would have struck a chord with me and shifted my worldview in some way. Seeing it now, I'm simply left wanting something more, and that may be a problem with me and not the movie itself.

Boyz N the Hood to me speak from a place that breaths life to the darkness, the soot and grime we want to keep in that very darkness. There is nothing I don't absolutely love about Boyz, and although I happen to be a super fan of Menace II, being that I have never seen anybody do what the Hughes Brothers do with a camera , I mean they do not need a budget, their imagination has imagination, they can get it done. Boyz to me, is the sort of pedagogue from which to learn, it assumes the meritorious titular teacher of the thematic film-making for more than just "lets roll and have some fun". But I came here because , time after time I experience Boyz, I just have to say one thing, Film cannot encapsulate everything that Mr. Singleton is, he is beyond words bearing the ineffable, not only in universal wisdom but in the arts of aesthetics. I would love to read something by Mr. Singleton in a sort of non-linear formless stream of consciousness about everything that is the great John Singleton....

reviews.review_title: A strong story indeed and a good background work for the now great stars
reviews.content: The story is very strong. At the very start the movie just plunges right into the substance of focus, the ongoing drive-by shooting in the hood. The complications added to the main focus are quite good. People may compare this to a similar movie such as City of God, and find that the story is not that strong. Yet the unique thing from this movie is that Boyz N The Hood looks at the hood from the perspective of a person who is not a 'player' in it. Still it' a good movie of a strong story. It's more suitable for the educational purposes than City of God. Cuba Gooding Jr, Lawrebce Fishbourne, and Ice Cube did a great job in portraying the residents of the ever menacing neighborhood of South Central.

This film has been heavily criticized for its excessive violence and misogyny towards women. It has been blamed for ushering in thug movies that stereotype and marginalize the black youth. But I would take a different view and say this film works as a classical neo-realist docudrama and reports to the world what is really going on in several parts of the black community. These were events that were not reported by news stations. John Singleton's characters not only show us what goes on but they give several sides of the issue to ponder. The director shows us three paths but in the end, John's message is to take the path of higher learning which happens to be the subject and title of his next film.Three Paths Doughboy Tre, and Ricky. Doughboy, Ricky and Tre make up the three paths or options for a young black man in South Central Los Angeles. Furious says that they're like brothers. Doughboy took the pathway of gang life. This path came with violence, prison and a deep bitterness towards life. Ricky became a football star. On this path he encountered a lot of parties and party girls.Ricky got a woman pregnant out of wedlock and now he's looking for football scholarship to get into college and take care of his family. Tre took the option of education and a minimum wage job in retail/ customer service. This comes with a steady Christian girlfriend that wants to wait until they get married before having sex.The Blessing Doughboy was cursed by his mother. He did not have a father figure; so, his absence spoke another curse over his life. The only love or blessing he got was from gang members and gang life. Ricky was favored by his mother. She blessed him and believed in his foot ball career. Girls in high school worshiped the ground he walked on. Everyone not only believed he could make it but they were counting on him to make it. When Tre was sent to live with his father his father protected him one night from a house burglar. With that blessing came several nuggets of wisdom. Tre's father Furious Styles taught him that violence is not the answer; he taught Tre to love his brothers; he taught him what it means to be a man and he taught Tre education is the way out.Education as a pathway outAt the end we're left with the idea that education is very very important. Doughboy believes that maybe if the right people were educated as to what was going on in their neighborhood, they would intervene and help. Tre goes off to college and Doughboy goes back into the concrete jungle. We see on the screen that Ricky's SATs were good enough for him to get into college, implying that education was a possible way out for him too.http://parablestoday.blogspot.com/2010/01/boyz-in-hood.html

The beginning of the 1990s was a scintillating time in Afroamerican culture signifying a wave of change. When hip-hop was about something apart from the bling-bling and social anger was fermenting just beneath the surface one important hallmark came in the emergence of true classic movies straight from black intellectuals - with Spike Lee and of course John Singleton the guiding light for future generations. "Boyz in the Hood" is a mix of "Godfather" and "City of God", equally pivotal as the mentioned classics, albeit maybe less artistically accomplished, as can be expected by a débutant.Set in the South Central district of Los Angeles "Boys in the Hood" is a cross examination of life within black ghetto neighbourhoods, bona fide war-zones, although mostly ignored at the times as irrelevant by police and white-led society. Focusing mainly on Tre Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr.), raised by his single dad Furious (Lawrence Fishburne), a true father figure and role model focused on his son's upbringing. His two best friends are brothers: Ricky (Morris Chestnut), an aspiring college football player and Doughboy (Ice Cube), the bad seed of the family, disowned and mistreated by his mother, who lays her hope in the more ambitious son. Growing up in neighbourhood, where - as opening credits inform - one in 21 people are murdered each of them tries to find solace in the situation or a way out.Each of the three main characters carries himself as a stereotype, but are also far from bland cardboard cutouts, instead seamlessly fitting into the prescribed roles envisaged to create a sense of hopeless hope permeating the society. Several scenes do unfortunately scream of amateurish overzealousness, like a tacky sex scene, which does little to deepen the story, fulfilling merely a melodramatic role. Nonetheless these are minor flaw in regards to the strong triumphant direction complimented with a forceful coming out by Cuba Gooding Jr. The drama is hard-hitting, whilst violence is so peculiarly banal in its presence, making the rough edges seem to compliment the overall tone. It is also worth mentioning the strong use of sound enforces the dread of the hood with ever-sounding tyres screeching, helicopters, police sirens and gunshots replacing typical background noise.John Singleton has in future outings proved to be a relative hit-and-miss, still waiting for another such prolific attack on American passiveness. Nonetheless even if he never makes anything of this generation-changing impact he is sure to become part of cinematographic history.

John Singleton clearly knows the first rule you learn in every writing class: make people care about your characters and then hurt them as much as you can. We get to know our main characters in their childhood through a long prologue, when they're still cute, innocent and even vaguely optimistic despite growing up in one of L.A's worst neighbourhoods. The first fifteen minutes or so are a clear homage to "Stand By Me", even though it might be rougher around the edges. The entire movie works because those early scenes are so well-written, it's painful when all their hopes are crushed later on. The movie is pretty fragmentary and doesn't really follow a coherent story, but thankfully they're just really good fragments. Singleton's bare-bones style combined with realistic performances from the entire cast makes this is an absolute jewel among American independents and one of the 90s' most influential movies.

reviews.review_title: John Singleton's impassioned debut still bristles with immediacy
reviews.content: "Boyz N the Hood" marked an impressive debut for writer/director John Singleton. This coming of age story set in South Central L.A. presented an eye-opening depiction of urban life in contemporary America. Its cultural significance was recognized in 2002 with its induction into the National Film Registry.The story's central character is Tre Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr.), a young man living with his father (Lawrence Fishburne) in the Crenshaw neighbourhood of South Central. At seventeen years of age, he and his closest friends are at a crossroads in their lives that could either lead out of the ghetto or into an early grave.The cast may have been composed of mostly unknowns at the time but it's an impressive ensemble in retrospect. Apart from the aforementioned involvement of Gooding & Fishburne, Ice Cube contributed a creditable performance in his first film role. Strong support was also supplied by Angela Bassett, Morris Chestnut, Nia Long & Regina King, among others.John Singleton's first time direction isn't particularly flashy but it got the job done and resulted in an Oscar nomination. Singleton also garnered a well-deserved Oscar nomination for his thoughtful script. Musically, the score & soundtrack haven't aged uniformly well but that's a minor point in the scheme of things.Ultimately, "Boyz N the Hood" represents one of the finest moments in African American cinema and still holds up well more than 20 years after its release. The authenticity of the writing, combined with a simple but powerful message, makes it a memorable and involving story for moviegoers of all backgrounds.

reviews.review_title: Tedious, irritating and overbearing with only one truly effective scene
reviews.content: I think that how good you find a film like Boyz N The Hood will ultimately depend on what you expect from it. The write up for this film suggests that it's going to be a deep and gritty film that explores the seedy underbelly of South Central. It also suggests that the characters involved will discuss various fundamental issues affecting their daily lives. I'm sorry, but if this is true then I clearly must have watched another film....This film does not explore its characters and doesn't even really explore the violence within South Central. It basically goes from scene to scene with all the 'kids' cussing each other and being disrespectful to their 'ho's'. Then thrown into the mix we have a million f-bombs and lots of shouting. The major problem with Boyz N The Hood is that for the most part it has an aimless, meandering feel to it where for most of its running time you never feel as though it's going anywhere. The dialogue exchanged between the characters is at best poor and at worst irritating. The relationships between the characters are poorly established (particularly between Tre and Furious) and this is unforgivable as this should have had much more focus than it actually did. Many of the characters are dull clichés (with the exception of Ricky and Furious). I've got to be totally honest and admit that I was bored for most of this film and considered switching it off at one point.There is one scene that was truly effective in this film and that was the scene where Ricky gets gunned down in a drive-by shooting. I actually found that scene very moving because Ricky was a likable individual - a family man who was on the verge of a scholarship. It was even more sad when you realise that he was always the one that kept out of trouble and was merely 'guilty by association'. I was genuinely moved by that scene and sadly that was the only good scene in the film.Of course this sets up the revenge aspect that we see in the final act and I only wish that Singleton would have focused more on the rivalry we saw towards the end rather than tedious melodrama that I had to endure for most of the running time.Boyz N The Hood is a good film that's trapped inside a terrible screenplay. Although its message is obvious from the start this still could have been a very good film if Singleton would have made the main story more compelling. As it is the tedious melodrama and dull and meandering nature of the narrative really killed this for me. Aside from the one effective scene, I found Boyz N The Hood a very hard film to care about.

The children in the world of Boyz n the Hood have never known a life without a police helicopter shuttling overhead. It has simply become part of the everyday scenery, much like the long faded letters of the police tape. The whirring of the blades serenade the characters throughout their journey; a young couple's first time, the lull after two brothers' final embrace, and so on. We see it early, in a crude crayon drawing that sticks sorely out of place. Police sirens are a similar recurring motif. For Tre and his friends it is not safety that is associated with these sounds, but another sin committed. It makes a bittersweet duet with The Five Stairsteps' O-o-h Child, the song crooning and pleading at the same time for sweet respite for these children. Only some though, have the father figures to do so.This is the most frustrating aspect of the film, in the way that it must cast off black women as problematic and dispensable in order to empower black men. Tre's mother Reva flits in and out of the film, with a vague dissatisfaction on the upbringing of his son despite it being her idea initially. She is a self-affirming ideal, by admitting that it takes a man to raise a man in the hood, something that she apparently cannot provide. She has betrayed her roots by rising above the hood and severing her connection to her son, and so becomes that stuffy stereotype of a divorced parent has no clue how to interact with their child other than showering them with gifts. While she is strong, Brenda is perceived as weak, abandoned by the fathers of both Doughboy and Ricky and desperately fending for herself. She is earmarked as the origin of Doughboy's rough pathway by Furious himself, a passive figure enabling the downfall of her children. Brenda pampers and babies Ricky up, treating him as a financial investment that might lift their family from the hood with his athletic talents. No doubt behind the scenes she is fussing over his shirt and tie before the big interview. And look for how frantically she tries to maintain the illusion of class in her home, brushing off the vermin (Doughboy and his lady) from the couch for the talk. But then Singleton does the nigh impossible, and manages to present a full-faceted character from within this sinking sandpit. He draws great conflict from making this a sympathetic act, something that we can hardly blame her for. It is motherly pride, and the least she can do is make sure Ricky gets his shot. The film makes note of the learned behaviour of the hood, and how it becomes a self-reinforcing cycle between generations. Even the venerable Furious is not spared from this fate; see him answer the phone crudely, and how Tre has picked up the same trait. In her own way, Brenda is also imposing the same vicious cycle, by immediately assuming the blame of Ricky's death lies with Doughboy. She is ultimately right, but that is beside the point - we feel for Doughboy, because this is just the last of a long line of influences that have reaffirmed the criminal path he has taken, and in doing so he knows no other reaction to his brother's death but more death. Early on, Ricky's apparent goodwill with his treasured football is received with hostility, and this becomes ingrained into the children's minds. They learn in the hood that to get what you want, you must take it for yourself. It comes down to Tre then, at the fork-road of his life, to make the right choice. He has the tricky challenge of rising above his friends and being a responsible young man without losing touch with them, which has always been a dilemma for the teenager. He would rather give his father a sexed-up, fantastic music video story about his first time than admit he has not 'gotten any pussy' yet. This later makes the scene of him losing his virginity all the more heart-wrenching; it comes after the primal release of pent-up emotions that goes against all that he has been taught. And yet later Furious must also fall to his level of logic, if only to dissuade him from making this biggest mistake of his life. Singleton is asking those in the hood to accept the responsibility of their actions, to speak up and step out of the car, and in the end Tre triumphs. And Doughboy acquiesces in his own way; he allows Tre to choose his own path, and sees so clearly and sadly how his is almost at its end.

I'm not sure I saw the same movie that others here saw. Not that I don't think it's a very strong effort by Singleton, it is. In fact, his later movies are quite disappointing in comparison. Where I may disagree with some is what this movie is about, and what it has to say. I won't pretend to know what the maker intended, but I know what it communicates to me about life in South Central Los Angeles. I'll start out by saying that I haven't the faintest idea whether this is a real life portrayal of "ghetto" America, since I've never spent two minutes in it. But taken as a discrete world, with characters created for it, I found this a very depressing place indeed. Larry Fishburne, in another wonderfully understated performance, plays "the conscience" but in fact seems to teach his son to blame someone else for the difficulties around him, an interesting inconsistency with his other lessons in self reliance and responsibility. It seems that many in this neighborhood are more interested in seeing that no one else escapes rather than escaping themselves, or bettering it. The structure of the community they live in isn't awful, in fact most live in smallish houses, but not hovels by any stretch. There seems to be money enough to buy the necessities if not the luxuries--no one is starving. And in fact the most hopeful sign is when the neighborhood comes together at a neighborhood picnic--a real sense of community comes through. Unfortunately it's only a glimmer. The various characters seem to be facing one form of hopelessness or another--even Ricky, attempting to accomplish something through sports is not a viable role model for most in that neighborhood, only the truly gifted manage to make it to scholarship athletics, and there are relatively few of those. Ice Cube, a rapper from the group NWA and not an actor by training, puts in an accomplished performance that a veteran actor would be proud of. When he says: "They don't know, don't show or don't care" about the "hood", it's as if he's waiting for someone to come and save him. That may be the voice of John Singleton, hard to say, but it runs counter to the idea that people make their own choices and should take responsibility for them. There's a streak of blame game in the movie--about how there some conspiracy somewhere that's causing all the misery. That's a dead end approach. That doesn't detract too much, since as I understand it, that's a real attitude that exists in some quarters. And the performances are uniformly well done--a good marriage of good acting and good writing, there's a lot for these folks to work with.

**Possible Spoilers**		The problems of inter-city culture, and what it's like to be a black youth growing up in South Central Los Angeles, is addressed by writer-director John Singleton in the   hard-hitting `Boyz N the Hood,' starring Laurence Fishburne and Cuba Gooding Jr.  The story centers on young Tre Styles (Gooding), whose parents are divorced, and as a troubled youth at age ten, is sent by his mother, Reva (Angela Bassett) to live with his father, Furious (Fishburne), in South Central.  The story then jumps ahead seven years, and we find Tre still living with his father. Furious is a man of principle, a decent man with high ideals, and he's done a good job of teaching Tre how to be a man, and how to survive without slipping through the cracks to become just another statistic from the hood, without hope of ever amounting to anything.  Furious is the calm in the eye of the storm, navigating a culture steeped in a seemingly never-ending cycle of violence.  Then when Tre is about to graduate from High School, and with his father's guidance is looking toward college, his best friend is shot and killed.  Tre wants to fight back; and suddenly, he must make the decision that will determine the path the rest of his life will take. 	Singleton successfully captures the alienation of an entire community from the rest of the city, and the atmosphere of violence that permeates the lives of all who live there; the incessant presence of the police helicopters a constant reminder, lest they forget for even a moment, where they are.  The anguish of the mothers who fear for the lives of their children, along with the frustration of the apparent futility of trying to make a change.  In Tre, Furious, and those close to them, Singleton paints a profound picture of what life is like for everyone who lives within that few square miles that is South Central Los Angeles.  A grim portrait, to be sure, yet in the end he manages to tone it with a positive sign; a glimmer of hope that there may yet be a light at the end of the tunnel for those born and raised in the inner-city. 	Fishburne gives a dynamic performance as Furious Styles, the voice of reason and truth amid the turmoil.  He knows who this man is, and his purpose; and it shows in the subtle command he takes whenever he is on the screen.  Gooding, too, gives a remarkable performance, aptly conveying the complexities of young Tre, the pride mixed with confusion.  The terrific supporting cast includes Morris Chestnut (Ricky), Ice Cube (Doughboy), Darneicea Corley (Keisha), Tyra Ferrell (Mrs. Baker), Redge Green (Chris) and Dedrick D. Gobert (Dooky).  Singleton is to be commended for having the courage to make a truly thought-provoking film.  For this is not a movie about gang-bangers; this is a film that has the guts to ask important and significant questions objectively, without copping an attitude.  About the cultural bias of the S.A.T.'s; why there's a liquor store or a gun shop on every corner in the hood, and not in Beverly Hills; and the lack of even the attempt at creating the symbiotic relationship that would benefit all who live in and around the city of Los Angeles.  This is an important film that goes far beyond the scope of mere cinema, and one for which Singleton will be remembered; it is definitely a movie that should be seen by all.  I rate this one 9/10.

reviews.review_title: What goes on in the hood?
reviews.content: "Either they don't know, don't show, or don't care about what's going on in the hood." These are the words of Ice Cube's character in the powerfully emotional race film, Boyz n the Hood, a story about a group of black kids who grow up in an impoverished and violent inner city neighborhood. It chronicles their lives as they grow up and turn into adults, some setting themselves up for greatness past the hood, while others are perpetually fastened in to the hood's violent gang straps. The film tells a moving story all fueled by racial tension within the black community and just how this affects the lives of those involved. It boasts numerous prominent black actors, many of whom were no names back when the film was released. It portrays a world and a lifestyle that some of us are all too familiar with and others, like myself, are very far from and never experience anything close to the impoverished absurdity that goes on within these "hoods." Boyz n the Hood is a fascinating watch and it is one of those films that can stick with you long after you watch it.Like I said, the lifestyle depicted in this movie is something so far fetched in my mind and it is something I can't relate to or hardly even comprehend as reality. I guess I have to blame my gaited little community of Texas suburbs and what is called "the bubble." But from what I understand, Boyz n the Hood is a very powerful depiction of the reality of these ghettos. And that is really the beauty and joy of a film like this. This kind of world is real and this society exists in our world and a movie like this allows us to witness the brutality of something like this. I don't experience this level of gang violence first hand but I certainly see it on the news enough and am exposed to it second hand via the media. But that's the media. They report facts rather than tell a dramatic story. Thus the dramatization of these kinds of real life situations through a movie like Boyz n the Hood makes that much more important. This movie is an eye-opener in the truest sense of the word.And apart from being socially significant Boyz n the Hood is really a well made film. The hood rat dialouge is very poignant and its vulgarian cadence is very consistent, albeit shocking at times. The mood of the hood setting is captured very well through John Singleton's visual eye and all of the sets seem very true to poverty stricken suburbs that look like they were built in the 60's. Plus all of the performances are excellent. This is basically the movie that began Cuba Gooding Jr's career and began his long run of great performances in the 90's. Laurence Fishburne's powerful performance is a given, but he does an excellent job Gooding Jr's father. Up until this point Ice Cube was only a rapper and Boyz n the Hood was his very first film appearance. And what an appearance it was. He delivers some of the most important lines in the film and does an incredible job when he has to. His is arguably the strongest performance in the entire film, believe it or not.As far as these "ghetto gangster" movies go, Boyz n the Hood fits in very well as one of the better ones. The most similar film to this that I can think of would be the Hughes Brother's Menace II Society from 1993 which is slightly better than this film for its own reasons. But it doesn't mean that Boyz n the Hood is an excellent film. It is very moving, very powerful, and very memorable. It is a worthwhile watch that will expose you to some very challenging, yet very real, things.

A+If there is a definite move I can recommend to almost anybody, among many, "Boyz n the Hood" would be one of my top picks. The genre of 'hood films' is one that is not popular outside of its targeted rap community, but this specific film is one that doesn't settle for simplistic broad character strokes that most would. John Singleton made inarguably his most personal film in his 1991 debut, and for a number of reasons.Firstly, it has an unflinching and striking depiction of the violence that flourished on the heated streets of this country. It helps to cement the realism and also captures the terror of the film's nicely done atmosphere. Secondly, the characters are not cardboard archetypes, many of them with distinct qualities. Tre's father, played by Laurence Fishburne , as well as his mother (Angela Bassett) both represent how the story offers much more than taking the easy way out with the character development; say for example just slapping a drunken loud-mouth stereotype in the setting.Then one can focus on the spectacular character study, and one can see how this crushing environment affects each character differently. I'd like to point out the golden performance of Cuba Gooding Jr. and. Both are intelligent young men with promising futures and both are committed to getting out of their bleak neighborhood. However, all around them are forces designed for them to fail, as Fishburne's character points out. This also brings me to the tragic character of Doughboy, played by Ice Cube. It's INARGUABLY his greatest role ever. The character is very intelligent yet nihilistic in a sense; he's succumbed to the 'streets' as it were. He seems self-aware of it all, a puppet who can see the strings, but he can never quite find the nerve to make a change. The use of mise en scene is of course to display a decrepit but very real look to the whole film, and it's masterful.I hate to spoil things, but there's a scene where a character is shot in the back, and our director makes it so devastatingly surreal. Everything stops: the yelling, the sound of running, and all you hear is the laughter of children. Then comes the gunshot, and the composer's fantastic score. My favorite scene though, among so many excellent ones, has got to be the conversation between Cuba and Cube at the climax. The word's shared, the hurt in Cube's voice, it all is just so painful when one lingers on what the film means.If you ever take psychology, or have a quick second to browse the vast internet, look up the term 'learned helplessness'.

reviews.review_title: "Any fool can make a son, but only a real man can raise his children."
reviews.content: I guess every one of us has one good movie script in us, our life story, and "Boyz N the Hood" was writer/director John Singleton's.  Only 23 when this film came out, Singleton's growing up in L.A. with a single real estate dad is the story of Tre (Cuba Gooding, Jr) in this film. Dad raises him to be responsible, and it pays off in the final battle scene when Tre asks to be let out of the car before his friends found and snuffed the guys who had killed Ricky earlier that day. As the captions at the end tell us, Tre went off to college in Georgia, and his girlfriend Brandi (Nia Long) was in college right across the street.The whole film depicts a gunfire-riddled neighborhood of mainly slackers. Every scene in the 'hood has at least one of the boys with a quart of beer that he is working on. All mothers are single. Kids find a dead body and don't think too much of it, except "it stinks." We learn all the conversational phrases of 1991 L.A. - What up? Who dat? Who dis? W'sup? We learn that one in 21 black men will be murdered, and most likely by one of their own.Aside from being mainly autobiographical, why was this film made? Simply as a statement? To show that it is possible to rise above the ghetto if you want to?  I don't know, but it sure puts in perspective a large issue within our society. Interesting to think of it in terms of Darwinian evolution, and the arguments presented in the book "The Moral Animal", which explores the psychology of survival of the fittest.

reviews.review_title: The best street gang film ever made
