Movies like this raise the question of whether movies are most important as arts of work on their own terms or as social statements made to have an impact on the world. Just by habit, I tend to lean towards the first view, and I would guess that most filmmakers do as well, since directors generally seem wary of discussing their work in terms of messages. But obviously not John Singleton; in the very first shot of Boyz n the Hood, the camera pushes towards a stop sign until it looms over the audience. This image sets the mood for the rest of the film, which has a strong impact that, as contradictory as this might seem, is somewhat blunted by the lack of subtlety. It belongs to that group of movies that probably stem most directly from Martin Scorsese's Mean Streets, a film that showed how talented young directors could make a splash with a debut set on their own home turf, particularly home turf far removed from the mainstream of American society. Not that Boyz n the Hood is anywhere as good as Mean Streets, but then I don't think that Singleton's main goal is to top Scorsese: he has a point to make. It's about the poverty and violence infesting South-Central L.A., with three main characters representing the basic options available to a young black man from that background. Cuba Gooding Jr. plays Tre, whose father, Furious Styles (Laurence Fishburne) is determined to raise him with the self-respect and discipline to avoid a life of crime and violence. His friend Ricky Baker (Morris Chestnut) isn't as smart but hopes to get into college on an athletic scholarship. Doughboy, meanwhile, is already immersed in gang life. The main performances are strong, particularly from Ice Cube, whose character is in man ways the most interesting, possessing the self-awareness his life is headed nowhere but not the will to do anything about it. At his strongest, Singleton creates a powerful, bleak portrait of a community under siege from guns, drugs, poverty, and general hopelessness, and he immerses you in this world as well, so that you share with the characters the same sense that all of the exits have been closed off. Whether or not you agree with all of the specific points that Singleton is trying to make, Boyz is unquestionably strong as a statement and a piece of reporting. It's far from a great piece of film-making; the music is intrusive and poorly done, and the story is overly melodramatic- it's not enough that one character has to be murdered to show the tragedy of gang violence, his friends then have to dump his bloody corpse in his living room so that we can see his mother's and his girlfriend's hysterical grief. But melodrama isn't really the main problem; it's more that Singleton's determination to get his message across frequently overwhelms his determination to tell a good story with believably individual characters. Too often the characters seem to be speaking to the audience instead of each other, sometimes to the extent that I expected them to turn towards the camera and issue a final warning. But for all of my criticisms of the movie, in the end I'm not sure how much they mean, because Singleton's focus, as I've already said, really doesn't seem to be on creating great art. If the success of a film is to be measured by whether it accomplishes what it sets out to do, rather than by one's enjoyment of it, than I think Boyz n the Hood would have to rate as a solid achievement.

The acting and dialogue were well done. The plot made sense and the pacing seemed normal not to fast or not to slow. This movie gives a well representation for what life was like for people living in the slums of LA. I enjoyed the movie and it was good. The themes that are discussed in the film are also interesting such as racism, crime, and the the type of brotherhood that hthey have going on around.Memorable: No Rewatchable: No.

reviews.review_title: A culture explored from the right perspective
reviews.content: There's so many ways you mess up what this movie tries to do, as can be seen in the many movies made after it in a similar setting. This movie is set on the streets, but it's not taking sides. It's not a romantic look at the life of the street thug, nor is it a patronizing tale of morals. It does not paint a picture of one group (the poor) against another (the rich). It's people in a community, and that community consists of all sorts of people, and they're all forced to face the reality they are in. I am in no position to judge how close to reality this movie is, but it all feels authentic.There are some great performances in this movie, and that goes all around. The big players and the bit parts are all played as if the characters were made especially for the actors. And all the characters feel like real human beings with struggles both big and small.

Let's start with a little history lesson, because I know some people might still have preconceptions about this movie.  Trust me, as likely as not, everything you've heard about "Boyz" makes it out to be exactly what it isn't.When "Boyz N the Hood" was first released ten years ago, I remember reading about how some theaters refused to show it.  They thought it was too inflammatory.  In hindsight, after watching the movie, I can't believe it. Why would a film that is so obviously against violence ever be imagined to inspire violence?Simply put, this movie is a must-see.  Just make sure you have a box of tissues within reach.  The ending is excruciating.

Even after more than 25 years since its raise, boys in the hood remains what I would call a cult classic. While the film does have its funny moments, but what's great about is how it deals what blacks had to go through in crime ridden Los Angeles and often trapped in the gang life because of limited opportunities and how the consequences of that life would result in jail, teen pregnancy, and death. The story deals with three friends, the, doughboy, and Ricky who try to navigate the struggles they go through on a daily basis while trying to avoid being trapped in the thug life.

This is one of my favorite movies about the black community along with Menace 2 society and Dead Presidents.This movie is one of the first in this genre and it is a touching story.It is also cool to see all the old school stuff in this movie.

This great script revolves around the coloured community in Crenshaw, following very interesting characters, albeit I found these to be quite stereotypical.Some unnatural dialogue decreased my involvement in an otherwise excellent screenplay. The camerawork and editing is primitive, but it did not do any harm compared with the great performances eliciting the oppression and institutionalization in this area of L.A. which still takes place today.As such, I think the film is timeless in its storytelling ability. Highly recommended.

This movie seems to be the first to successfully portray the harsh circumstances that frequently comprise life in the urban ghetto. It neither romanticizes nor trivializes the brutal violence that falls disproportionately on the urban Black community. It deals frankly and unapologetically with the social circumstances that contribute to the atmosphere, from within the Black community (participation in the illicit drug trade, rampant absentee fatherhood) and from outside (apathy, exploitation of racial tensions).Two acting highlights: a) a somewhat green Cuba Gooding Jr. shows promise in his major acting debut; b) rap star Ice Cube demonstrates he is a surprisingly good actor, considering he had no prior acting experience. Gooding has since made good on his promise (see Jerry Maguire), and Ice Cube has similarly demonstrated an astonishing natural and versatile talent for acting (see Fridays, Three Kings).Final vote: 8 of 10

BOYZ N THE HOOD is a very good movie.It starts a bit ordenal, but neccesary to the story, but when the kids grow up the movie really start to take shape and we see some great acting (Even Ice Cube & C:O was charming) and lovely family-portrait. Laurence Fishburne hangs along the entire movie with his preaches, and I still wonder if he shows justice to Tre, or if he's being too hard. I can't make up my mind. Then eventually things start to go wrong, and at the end you are touched, as usual in the ghetto-genre. This was a bit of a start for Cuba Gooding Jr, a very good actor that I have respect for, e.g fantastic performances in JERRY MAGUIRE and AS GOOD AS IT GETS. He is very good, and his Tre in BOYZ N THE HOOD is defenitly no excuse. Ice Cube also proves that he can do more than rap, and that is something that most rappers don't really do (take a look at Ice-T).
John Singleton, well, as a director he's good I guess, I haven't seen others of his work, and honestly for a director, compared to other movies, I doubt that this was a difficult movie to make. It is touching, gripping and strong. A very good movie that makes one show respect for life. 8.5/10

I just saw Stand by Me the other day and it reminded me of this movie. Am I saying that Stand by Me, a movie about four white kids in Castle Rock, Oregon, is anything like Boyz n the Hood, a movie about young blacks in Compton, California? Absolutely not. But, there was the opening scene of Stand by Me which rang a bell. "Do you want to see a dead body?" is what Vern asked his three other buddies. There were absolutely no other parallels after that. In fact, the bodies were abandoned victims for two different reasons. The first, a kid that was hit by a train and missing in the woods. The second, a victim of murder.Boyz n the Hood was one of, if not the grittiest and realest movie I've ever seen about life in the 'hood. Until 1991 Colors was the only movie I knew of addressing impoverished black neighborhoods with gang problems. I think it was because of this movie that movies like Menace to Society, South Central, Juice and others were made. I don't know that John Singleton has directed a better movie to this date.I would say that Boyz n the Hood was exactly what some needed to see and too much for others. The lifestyle and conditions portrayed were not glorified so as to make it seem cool to be involved in gangs and drive-bys, yet it wasn't overly despondent whereby you get the feeling that everyone in the hood is doomed. I think it was a good depiction of how life is on the other side of the tracks and it was well done.

"Boyz n the Hood" overflows with talent both on and off the screen, as it's astounding that John Singleton was only 22-years-old when he both wrote and directed this film.Nothing in "Boyz n the Hood" projects the idea that this is a directorial debut. The camera buzzes around, capturing the harsh aspects of life in the Crenshaw ghetto. Police sirens blare, helicopters buzz overhead, and gunshots go off like clockwork. It makes for an exhausting viewing experience and creates the empathy required to know how exhausting it is to live like this everyday.With Laurence Fishburne's Furious Styles acting as his mouthpiece, Singleton illustrates his thesis statements, such as environmental racism and breaking the wheel of violence.There's both style and substance within the film, leaving you both entertained and educated.

"Boyz n the Hood" is an extraordinary film that shows life in the hood for a group of young boys just trying to survive in it. Of course what made this film so good is that a lot of its viewers can relate to or grew up in situations similar to what this film is about but rather or not you grew up in the hood you will enjoy this film for the fine piece of work it is. As well written and directed as this film is it's almost easy to tell that this is one of John Singleton's first pieces of work. From looking at his later films and seeing it now from the way I look at films now "Boyz n the Hood" does look a little amateurish but it is still a magnificent piece of work! The casting is almost perfect! They couldn't have found better actors to play the parts in this film even if they tried. To say Ice Cube never played in a film before this one says a lot about his talents. Even the smallest unnoticeable things Ice Cube did in this film were convincing. Another good thing about this film is the messages that are spread though out it. Everything from demeaning women, racism, police brutality, gangbanging, and gentrification is talked about in this film which also makes this a film for everybody to learn from and enjoy. Overall, this film is a master piece that probably won't be matched by any other of its kind. As one reviewer wrote, "The best ghetto film of all time." Oh, and with the soundtrack to this film you get double the pleasure because it was just as dope!

The best and most realistic movie about a group of boys growing up in the hood. It follows them from their youth through high school, showing how their lives take different turns while dealing with the environment that they live in. It shows the realism of gang violence and the consequences of it. I think that's one thing that sets this movie apart from others in the genre. You really care about these characters and what happens to them. Excellent performances by all the actors and the first and best film directed by John Singleton. "Increase the Peace" **** (Out of 4)

Boyz N the Hood is one of many early films that bring awareness to the struggles of life "in the hood." Three boys grow up together in the Crenshaw ghetto of Los Angeles, and although they are all different in their own ways, they all have to deal with the problems that come with living in a dangerous, low-income area. BoyZ N the Hood not only explores socio-economic problems, but explores issues of race that are not as simple as black against white. The angle that this film has does not solely blame the white majority for all the social problems that South Central LA faces, but raises questions about what blacks do to each other in their own neighbourhoods. In the final credits, "Increase the Peace" is written in bold letters, a nice finishing touch to the film's thesis. This is a beautiful, heartbreaking film. An oldie, but definitely worth the watch and is still relevant today.

reviews.review_title: A gripping tale of life in the crime ridden suburbs of LA
reviews.content: This film has a special meaning for me as it reflects something very similar that happened in real life to me. The two main characters Tre and Ricky are introduced to us as young boys and become firm friends. As the movie fast forwards to present day the viewer gets the the feeling that you personally feel the pain that these two characters are going through.Tre is caught between his mother and father who have separated and is fighting with his feelings for them whilst trying to cross over into manhood whilst living in the gangland killing fields of LA. Ricky would like to get into college to pursue his football career the only way out for him and his young family to a better way of life.By the end of the movie you feel that if only friends would listen to one another more often and say the things that really matter in their relationships then when it's time to say goodbye you know how you feel about one another.A must see film if you have ever had a best friend who is no longer around. It will definitetly make you want to repair all of those friendships that have fallen by the wayside before it's too late. An 8/10.

Rarely do I watch a movie where I really get sucked into the action and almost never feel compelled to look at my watch.  This was the kind of experience I had watching this movie.  John Singleton wrote and directed a deeply inspired coming-of-age drama that gives his audience a picturesque look at what it's like to grow up in the hood.  Yet Singleton never gets overly sentimental.  He tempers much of the drama with humor.  The performances are right on target.  Sometimes I see now-famous actors in their earlier works and I'm not as impressed.  That wasn't the case with Cuba Gooding, Jr. who absolutely shines in this early performance.  Needless to say, Laurence Fishburne and Angela Bassett also give powerful performances, both of whom possess intense screen presences.  Ice Cube probably gives the best performance of his career.  He has proved in other movies that he's a decent actor, but in this one he actually proves to be good.  I tend to be a sucker for these types of coming-of-age stories, like "A Bronx Tale" and "This Boy's Life," but every once in a while a bad one comes along.  This is definitely not one of them!  I laughed, I was moved, I was riveted.  Plus, I must mention that the film breaks away from certain stereotypes among African=Americans.  For example, Tre's parents aren't on welfare and food stamps, but people with decent jobs that pay decent salaries, as well as being well-educated.  Of course, South Central does have its share of deadbeat, crackhead mothers and others of that sort, and they are portrayed as well in this film.  But they don't compose the whole S.C. population.  "Boyz N the Hood" IS really as great as it was hyped up to be.  It's a powerful, emotionally-charged drama that you won't soon forget! 
My score:  9 (out of 10)

Ice Cube failed in Anaconda but I gave him another shot in Boyz 'N he Hood. The gang life is not easy and making a movie about it can be even harder, probably not but I wouldn't know. With the title and summary of the movie I knew this could be one of two movies, one, a violent bloodbath of gang violence with obvious characters and little story, or the exact opposite. Boyz 'N the Hood has really good characters, a deep and meaningful story, and a well developed look in the gang life of California. I don't know how accurate this movie is to the gang life in the 1990s but I felt sympathy for all the characters living in that life and it is hard to believe people actually live like that in real life.The story follows the life of Tre, a really intelligent, black, man struggling with the life he lives in. Lawrence Fishburne plays Tre's father and he is an incredible character. I will start this review praising his awesomeness and knowledge of the real world. He is a man who understands the life he lives in and he does not want that for his son. From a very young age he teaches his son how to be a man and how to avoid the life. He is a great role model for his son and brings a lot of depth to the movie. There is a scene when he prevents gang violence and goes on a rant about why the hood is the hood. He says something along the lines on the government wants blacks to kill each other. On every corner of the ghetto there is a liquor store and a gun store. That is the true meaning of the movie, or the deeper meaning. Gang violence destroys people's lives and it is pointless. The movie exaggerates how the gangs know it is pointless but they do it because they have to. Ice Cube's character hits on this point too, being the gangster of the movie and the head of his own crew. Its characters like Tre and Ricky which give people hope. Fishburne and Ice Cube did fantastic in the roles they were given. They went above and beyond and put more than 100% in their performance but Cuba Gooding Jr. plays Tre as an adult and he was underwhelming. I'm not the biggest fan of Cuba Gooding Jr. I don't think he is a great actor but I think he was a good choice for the role. Tre seemed almost unimportant and I don't think it was because of how the story was written, I believe it was because of how he was acted. Tre is different. He doesn't want to live the thug life. He wants to be a success and movie out of the hood. Gooding Jr. didn't act that out so well. His character was boring at times and it took all the way to the end to get any emotion out of him. I liked his character as a kid way better than an adult. That's a huge complement on the child actor, or a slap in the face to Cube Gooding Jr. you decide. Towards the middle of the movie Ricky has a chance to go to college. Ricky is a great character as well. He isn't so smart but he is good at football. He was another example of people wanting to get out of the hood and his only chance was football. This is the case for a lot of young people trapped in the gang life. Unfortunately, his story was more than predictable and half way through the movie I knew exactly how it was going to end. I wasn't surprised by the ending at all but it didn't take away from the movie as much as I thought it would. The very last scene with Tre and Ice Cube was so emotional and deep it saved the movie for me. It made me able to look past the predictability and enjoy the movie. Throughout this review I mention the thug life or the gangster life and I did not expect so much detail of the life in the movie. At one point there is a little girl in a diaper and Tre picks her up before a car hits her. Tre returns her to her mother and all the mother cares about is getting a fix. She didn't care about her child and wanted cocaine instead. "You selling rocks." She says. I know it's a movie but I believed that happens in real life and it made me sick. I like how Tre had a great relationship with his father. I expected him and his father to clash heads and argue, but they didn't. In more ways than one this movie surprised I liked it way more than I thought I would. Overall, Boyz 'N the Hood was very emotional, very impactful, very practicable, but very good and I can see myself watching it again and again. I can look past the obvious endgame and enjoy the cinematic experience. Ice Cube gave me a surprising performance while Cuba Gooding Jr. disappointed me. Lawrence Fishburne gave the best performance I have ever seen him in and I expected nothing less. With a title like Boyz 'N the Hood I expected the violent bloodbath. I did not expect the emotional roller-coaster and lovable and relatable characters. This movie surprised me a lot and I'm proud to give it the WillyT Honorable Mention.

The first time I saw "Boyz In The Hood" it really moved me.  The powerful writing, and the rich characters are what make this movie memorable.  Even though there have been parodies against this movie, it still has a strong & powerful message.  It explored the plight of South Central L.A. without sugar coating it with dance routines, and lame comedy.  John Singleton aimed for the jugular when he directed this masterpiece of growing up in South Central, and he succeeded in delivering the message that there is a war going on in our citie's neighbourhoods that cannot be ignored any longer. This was also the first John Singleton movie that I ever saw of his.  Since this one he has maintained a steady stream of great movies like "Poetic Justice" and "Baby Boy", just to name a couple.  "Boyz In The Hood" was a must get for my video library, because even though it was made 12 years ago, the message of this movie remains pertinent today: "Increase The Peace".

One of the few films about blacks made BY blacks, this was ahuge hit  when it came out in the early nineties. With a wonderfulcast, this is a film about family disintegration and gang wars, veryviolent, yes, but with a heart. As Emanuel Levy says in his bookabout the independent film movement, "Cinema of Outsiders", 'Boys 'N' the Hood' demythologizes ghetto life, while advocatingself-sufficiency, and features another novelty- none of the womenis a prostitute, servant, or welfare mother- all demeaning roles thatblack women have been assigned to play in Hollywood movies."Worth a look indeed.

reviews.review_title: A Masterpice on The Truth About Urban Life
reviews.content: This Movie Was A Masterpiece, And Should Be Shown At Every School In Every Major City Showing What Can Happen If You Make The Wrong Choices. I Know It Would HAve Possibly Made A Impact On My Friends And Family If It Had Been Shown At School Or Something Like It. But It Is The Most Accurate Depiction Of Urban Life Of Any Film Or TV Show Even To Current Date. It Has Helped Me Cope With Urban Life And I Have Been Out Of Prison For 2 Years. I Have This Movie To Thank For That. It Showed Me What Will Happen If I Stayed On The Path I Was On. But Ice Cube Is At His Acting Best As Is Cuba Gooding Jr. Larry (Laurence) Fishburne And Morris Chestnut. There Still Has Yet To Be A Movie Like It. Or Even Close To It. In Closing Id Like TO Say You Should Watch This Movie If You Haven't Yet. Or Buy It If You Love It And Don't Already Own It. I Just Purchased It On Its Anneversary 2 Disc DVD Set And Love It. Thank For Reading This Hope It Was Useful And I Hope You Love The Movie Or Buy It. InCrease The Peace
This movie is so damn good. I was hooked right from the start. Amazing acting, cast, setting and story. I 100% RECOMMEND

reviews.review_title: I make dough, but don't call me doughboy
reviews.content: This is a great movie. I've seen a lot of dramas about the hood, but this is one of the best. The script has expertly trimmed the fat. The story doesn't lag, and it all feels necessary. Excellent performances by Laurence Fishburne, Ice Cube, and Cuba Gooding Jr. Good soundtrack and cinematography. A classic.

I remember seeing this debut film from Oscar nominated director John Singleton (Shaft, 2 Fast 2 Furious) in college, I could only picture the certain moments, so I really wanted to see it again. Basically it focuses on three young African American boys growing up in South Central inner city Los Angeles in the hood, i.e. surrounded by violence, alcohol, crime and drugs. Ten year old Tré (Desi Arnez Hines II) is left by mother Reva Devereaux (Angela Bassett) to live with father Jason 'Furious' Styles (Laurence Fishburne), and he hangs with his ten year old trouble making friends, half-brothers Doughboy (Baha Jackson) and Ricky (Donovan McCrary), and also Little Chris (Kenneth A. Brown). Seven years later, the three friends have stuck with each other through their approaching adulthood, and all are going different directions in the tough neighbourhood. Tré (Cuba Gooding Jr.) still living with his father is still learning how to be real man, while making a relationship and losing his virginity with Brandi (Big Momma's House's Nia Long). Ricky (Morris Chestnut) is trying to become a professional all-American athlete by getting a scholarship in sports, specifically football, but finding it hard to do. Doughboy (Ice Cube) is still big and lazy, and occasionally getting involved with the violence, alcohol, and crime around, but not losing sense of pride or honour. The most challenging scene is where Ricky has offended a gang of thugs, and Tré witnesses them gun him down in cold blood, on the day he would have received his test results. While Mrs. Baker (Tyra Ferrell) and others are screaming with shock and despair, Tré planned to go with Doughboy to find the gang and shoot them dead, but after some words from father Furious, he changes his mind at the right time. In the end, Tré and Doughboy part ways but on good terms, and the final texts reveal what they did next, half good half bad. Also starring Redge 'Regi' Green as Chris and Meta King as Brandi's Mom. It is amazing to think director/writer Singleton was only twenty-three at the time, and with a brilliant cast of black actors, great scripting, and quite a powerful premise of growing up in rough areas, it is definitely a must see drama. It was nominated the Oscar for Best Writing, Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen for Singleton. It was number 19 on Film 4's 50 Films To See Before You Die. Very good!

reviews.review_title: Deserves All The Praise It Gets.
reviews.content: Spike Lee's "Do The Right Thing" in 1989 was the start of the "hood" film genre. Two years later, young director John Singleton did his first film that has since been regarded as the mother of all hood movies. I do think that "Do The Ring Thing" is better, but Boyz N the Hood has more humanity and has more morals, which is why it is still raved as being the best of the genre.Boyz N the Hood is a coming-of-age film about a group a young people living in Compton. Cuba Gooding Jr. stars in the centre of the film as Tre Styles, a smart kid who is bound for bigger and better things. As a child, he was given full custody to his father, Furious Styles (Laurence FIshburne) so that he doesn't grow up like other people is LA's ghetto. Furious is an investment broker and Vietnam War veteran, who is determined to raise his son with the proper obedience. Morris Chestnut and Ice Cube co-star as siblings who are Tre's best friends. Them and a few of their friends do their best to stay out of trouble. But robberies and gang violence are part of the everyday. The whole time, we wonder how the pacifism that Furious taught will actually remain a part of their lives.We get a perfect glimpse into South Central Los Angeles. The police abuse their power on its residents. Its not much of a race-related thing since one of the most brutal cops is black. It is about class. Los Angeles is divided, and the ghetto is too. There's a very famous scene where the a gang cons Ricky into taking his football. But aside from that, there's always rival gangs in ghettos. Not only are we taken into this neighbourhood, but the characters that inhabit this area are real. Ricky loves football, Doughboy is the fat brother who got the short end of the stick, and Tre wants out. Simple gang violence leads to deaths. Tre may have to go against his father's orders in order to ensure survival.This is a very precious film about survival and loyalty. Tre and his friends are lucky to grow up around somebody like Furious. It is not a a movie with black guys swearing and killing like so many other hood movies are. There are actual messages and life lessons, with real characters that draw us into a real place.Do The Right Thing started the genre, but Boyz N the Hood remains in its top spot.4/4

This was, simply put, an amazing and remarkably powerful film. John Singleton captures the true essence of the problems in Compton by filming this in South Central LA and by pulling no punches. This is a story which needed to be told and needed to be conveyed in as brutally honest a manner as possible. There are no cliches here, just honesty in the storytelling.Technically speaking, the acting and direction were brilliant. Lawrence Fishburne is a fantastic actor and did not disappoint. Neither did Gooding or Ice Cube, both of whom gave extremely moving performances. Take note of the scene in which Gooding goes to his girlfriend's house after being harassed by cops.One of my favorite scenes in this film involves Styles (Fishburne) describing to Trey and Ricky the ways that society is turning them and their neighbors against one another and about the need to unite in order to save their neighborhoods, rather than continuing to fight one another. It is a central theme throughout the film and it is one which we should all consider.A brutally honest film with a critical message:Increase The Peace

reviews.review_title: How to get the Boyz n the Hood to Increase the Peacke
reviews.content: Some films hang around at the back of your mind for days, like the aftermath of a bad dream, influencing your mood and giving you a feeling that all is not well, for no apparent reason. John Singleton's" Boyz n the Hood" (1991) did that to me. If I could sum it up in one image, it would be that of a kid lowering the car window and pointing his gun at anything that caught his attention. It conjures up a darkness, a barbaric senselessness, an uncivilised malevolence that infects the spirit.I was surprised at the difference between the two halves of the film when watching it again recently. The first seems to be infused with light. OK. Laurence Fishburne unleashes his gun on an intruder in his house the night he takes in his son. He has accepted the responsibility of caring for him at the request of his ex-wife, who wants to concentrate on finishing her masters degree in teaching and establishing her own career. Fishburne's physical resemblance to Samuel L. Jackson always leads me to expect a "And I will strike down upon thee with great vengeance and furious anger those who attempt to poison and destroy My brothers" kind of tirade every time his bulky frame fills the screen. Instead we get the warm and cuddly velvet glove over the just as powerful, iron fist threatening presence. We saw that persona in Michael Apted's 1991 film, "Class Action", in which Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio produced a female version of the Samuel L. Jackson style of acting.So, after violently defending the home he will share with his son, we see him him singing along with his favourite soft soul music song on the car radio and spending time fishing and passing on his philosophy of life. That's the first half of the filmThe second is so much darker. Now the father is preaching to his son, his friend and interested bystanders on the need for African Americans to retain the identity they have given to their neighbourhoods and to resist the seductive offers by real estate agents bent on acquiring their houses with a view to gentrifying those areas.The son (Tre ,played by Cuba Gooding Jr.) and his football champion childhood friend and neighbour (Ricky Baker, played by Morris Chestnut) are both determined to improve their prospects in life by means of getting a tertiary education. But then the dark forces of meaningless violence masquerading as a means to earn 'respect' impinge upon their quest to leave their troubled environment.Paradoxically, it is the innocent, mild mannered Tre who sets the tragic events in motion, when he objects to being shouldered out of the way by an outsider at the local hangout. That action unleashes the forces of evil, revenge and vendetta. It is powerful stuff. Tre opts out of the savagery. Ricky and his delinquent brother are murdered.At the conclusion of the film, Singleton places the words, "increase the peace" on the screen.In the context of the film, that gesture is quite dramatic. But in the cold light of day - it is just words. How can anyone "increase the peace" in such an environment. And it is not just the 'drive by shooting' infested areas of inner city Los Angeles. Australians were sobered on 21 August 2013 by an event described by CNN as "A random act of violence has left a promising 23-year- old college baseball player dead, a family devastated and two countries half a world apart rattled. Christopher Lane, who was from Australia, was gunned down in Duncan, Oklahoma, while he was out jogging last week. The motive? Three teens who had nothing better to do, according to police."That got me thinking about how Americans, with their fiercely protected rights to bear arms could "increase the peace'. It brought to mind the concept of "hot spot policing". (New York mayor Rudolph Giuliani corrupted the initial concept and turned it into "zero tolerance policing"). Hot spot policing worked on the basis that some areas had effectively been turned into war zones. Violence reigned. So the authorities instituted a TEMPORARY version of "zero tolerance policing". Once order had been restored, and the forces of darkness had been moved on, the heavy policing of that locale ceases. So what about the argument it is just shifting the problem elsewhere. It is not a problem. When the problem moves to a new location, a new "hot spot policing" area can be declared for the area to which they have moved, and the same processes can be instituted. Areas should only be declared to be hot spots for a defined time. The status should be temporary - not permanent. So why not ban all weapons from such "hot spot policing" in public areas? All such weapons would be seized by the police and destroyed in a weekly public ceremony within seven days of seizure.Such a policy should not need to an affront to members of the NRA. People, like Tre's father, who keep their guns at home for use against intruders would not be affected. It would only be those involved in drive by shootings, or those who carry guns with them as a means to demand "respect" in places that could be temporarily declared to be "hot spots"Australia (which does not have any right to bear arms laws) instituted a "gun buy back" for automatic weapons after a gruesome mass shooting in 1996. The gun buy-back scheme started on 1 October 1996 and concluded on 30 September 1997.The buyback purchased and destroyed more than 631,000 firearms, mostly semi-auto .22 rimfires, semi-automatic shotguns and pump-action shotguns. (Wikipedia)How's that for increasing the peace?

reviews.review_title: Still packs a punch some years later-the ultimate ghetto film
reviews.content: After his Cannes triumph and a remarkable box office return on the dollar when it hit theatres in the summer of 1991,John Singleton's writing/directing debut feature "Boyz In The Hood" got him dual Oscar nominations at the ripe young age of 24. Juggling half a dozen characters with ease it was a cautionary tale about three friends through young adulthood in a impoverished neighborhood where life and death was a constant struggle to survive against impossible odds. This was a movie that dealt upfront with the trials and tribulations of a young man's growing up in the mean streets of South-Central Los Angeles,California. This was a movie that hit a nerve with its audience and it shows in detail of a young man's odds to survive at all costs in a hellhole of a ghetto where poverty and violence were everyday occurrences. This was a movie that gave the audience a profound look at life on the streets and gets a realistic approach to the everyday happenings that are out there and the dangers that are out there,especially the gangs. Even after 15 years later,it still packs a punch and stands up very well with the standards of today.This was the ultimate "ghetto" film which will never be topped. The movie "Boyz In The Hood",came out during a slew of films of that period including "New Jack City"(1991),the Hughes Brothers' "Menace II Society"(1993),and "Jason's Lyric"(1994). Even fifteen years ago,the film,"Boyz In The Hood" brought some of the new fresh faces in black cinema at the time and they after this movie went on to bigger and better things. Newcomers Cuba Gooding,Jr.(who played Tre Styles) and Morris Chestnut(his best friend Ricky),along with Nia Long,Regina King and even Angela Bassett(who plays Tre's mom)present excellent performances,but the real performances from this movie come from Laurance Fishburne,who was memorable as the complex authority figure-the single dad who raises his son in a hostile environment where he worries that his son could be killed at any moment. The "real" performance comes from the debut of rapper/actor Ice Cube as "Doughboy" is enough to make the film stand out. Even for a actor who is better known for his explicit lyrics on records,Ice Cube gives the most realistic performance that I have ever seen and it shows in his breathtaking and memorable range as an actor. A must see film.MPAA Rating: "R"-For Strong Graphic Language and Graphic Violence and Gore with scenes of Nudity,Sexual Content,Racial Situations. Running Time of 107 Minutes. Released by Columbia Pictures.

reviews.review_title: This is a film that in its climate perhaps needed to be made - and we ALL should be thankful it exists...
reviews.content: Cinema that for once speaks the language of the streets - a language that maybe even crosses racial divides. As a film it's got an unfair reputation in my neighbourhood that comes from all the wannabe gangsta's hoping to emulate some of the lifestyles that they've seen on screen. One can't help lamenting that in aspiring to this they've missed the point entirely. "Menace II Society" is another one THAT crowd all adore; but unfortunately I haven't had an opportunity to watch the latter just yet. I'm unsure how you make a film that's honest in its verisimilitude without at least PARTIALLY glamourizing - I guess that would be why I'm not a director, then... !The 'elevator' type music occasionally in the background sometimes lends this the air of a daytime soap; especially coupled with the movie adopting somewhat of a 'sermonizing' tone every now and then, complete with symbolism that some might well consider 'overdone' (extreme closeup of the 'Stop' sign at the beginning, for example!) This brand of heavyhandedness belongs somewhere else; threatening to undermine as it does the gritty urban subject matter.One of the many things the film DOES have in its favour though is a wealth of talented black performers - Fishbourne in particular doing yet more superb work that makes it all the easier to spot when he's 'coasting' in other projects (a la "The Matrix"!) Everybody brings a 'weight' and a strong sense of 'social conscience' to the enterprise that's belied in a way by the silly 'street slang' of the title. No trivial, cursory examination of the issues, this. Singleton establishes the tone quickly by exerting a strong directorial control that I'm willing to admit pleasantly trumped any preconceptions I may've held before watching. Constantly there is a violent undercurrent and a persistent feeling that anything is capable of happening within the narrative world that has been so disturbingly recreated. We must never forget that for many people this life is of course a reality, and not merely a diverting fiction, as I might be tempted to think of it in the reasonably affluent white lifestyle that I lead. Not of course that one should feel guilty about the relative safety that one was borne into; but it's films as accomplished as this one that are capable of jarring people out of their comfort zones and forcing them to look at life on the other side of the fence. It's an experience that can only make you a better person should you give yourself into it. "Boyz N the Hood" represents a crucial landmark in cinematic history. 10/10.

This is, without a doubt, Singleton's truest and best film of his career. Never before had a movie perfectly captured the friction and turbulence of the streets. The movie received well-deserved Oscar noms for script and direction, but how could they have overlooked Laurence Fishburne? As Furious Styles, Fishburne delivers a rock-solid performance as a father schooling his son on how to overcome the hardships of being a black man in modern society. Ice Cube came just as strong; his insights in the film are deep; they reflect the hardness and torment of Doughboy. This film, like "Pulp Fiction" and countless others, spawned similar-themed dramas ("Juice", "Menace II Society", "Above The Rim", "New Jersey Drive"), and while they had their moments, Singleton's debut outshines them all. You owe it to yourself to see this one.

Most people may consider this movie to be in the category as a "ghetto film", but as to me and maybe even others, its a relating film. I say this because each event that has happened in this movie is similar to events that i have seen during my life. Considering my point of view, this movie was basically based on a couple of young men growing up in the hood struggling trying to protect themselves from the all the dangers of the South Central streets. This movie relates to a lot of what really goes on in these types of communities.In the movie, there was one part that caught my attention which was when Doughboy(Ice Cube) was on the porch talking to Tre(Cuba Gooding Jr.)and said exactly "Either they don't know, it don't show, or they just don't care about whats going on in the hood." As of speaking for my past, I did believe that specific quote. Back then, when you would turn on the news, they would almost never tell about incidents that happened in the hood. Because of that, i can really relate to how Doughboy was feeling in the movie. Even though Doughboy rarely showed any emotion to how he felt, i could still feel the pain that he would go through daily. The impression that the actors gave me in the movie felt so realistic. You could tell that they held anger in their hearts because of the things that would happen in their community. In my opinion, the turning point of the movie was when Doughboy brother,Ricky(Morris Chesnut), got shot and killed. The bad thing about it was that he was one of the few in their hood that was actually trying to get to college and make something of his life. When he got killed, i felt that everybody came to a "breaking point". Ricky's brother, along with his friends, found the need to seek revenge. They felt that the guy who shot Ricky, owed them his life. I can just imagine how Doughboy felt when he had to carry his own dead brother into their home and try to explain to his mother what happened. The thing that bothered me was that when Mrs.Baker(Tyra Ferrell) broke down and started accusing Doughboy of killing her son Ricky.Even though Doughboy and Ricky did get into a fight earlier before Ricky got shot, Mrs.Baker should have known better that her own son would never kill his own brother. This, I could tell enraged Doughboy. On the other hand, Tre,being the loyal friend he was, felt that he also needed to catch revenge on the people that killed Ricky. To me, Tre was actually one of the lucky ones that actually had a father to look up to at the time. His father Furious(Laurence Fishburne)was like Tre's guardian angel. It was his father that had to talk him out of catching revenge on the guys that killed Ricky. Even though Ricky was one of Tre's best friends, Tre's father did not want him to go out there and mess up his life and end up in jail like the many others. Even though Tre did leave with Doughboy to go catch revenge, he did not go through with it. Tre actually took the advise giving by his father and just left the situation in the hands of Doughboy and the others. Overall I can say that this is one of my top favorite movies. I really enjoyed the actors because they fit so well with their character. The showed great amounts of emotion from their anger, their tears, and their sincerity in their words. To me, this has been marked one of the greatest works of John Singleton and shall be remembered for many years to come.

reviews.review_title: An intensely felt, moral journey to the "hood."
reviews.content: Boyz N The Hood is the tour de force first film by writer/director John Singleton.  He gives us fascinating and tragic story of living in "the hood," the poorer, almost all Black and Hispanic sections of Los Angeles. It shows us the story of Tre (Cuba Gooding Jr.), as he tries to make good decisions in the face of a world where good decisions are rarely rewarded. It shows the conflicting values of loyalty, honor, pride, and vanity, and how to deal with them in a place where going to the store can get you killed.  This danger brings a sense of dread to even the most innocuous scenes.  The danger serves the dual purpose of making us even more invested in these characters, and more importantly, to give insight to the constant fear that pervades "the hood."  Yet, Singleton makes an intensely moral film that argues that restraint, effort, and self reliance are the ways to make it out of "the hood."   Lawrence Fishburne plays Tre's father as the moral center in this film that is strong, fair, tough, and in its own way, perfect.

reviews.review_title: Temptation is not sin; yielding to temptation is!
reviews.content: This premier "Hood" movie by John Singleton has spawned a legion of dreadful imitations! "Boyz" opened the door for other aspiring filmmakers to get their urban narratives told on the big screen. However all those other imitations, emulations, and duplications did not get the anti-violent message that Singleton tried to communicate!Every "Hood" movie put out had masterful direction in expressing  the problems in Urban America. The "Homeys" don't need to see a Hood movie to know that there is a problem! They can see the problem! They can hear the problem! They LIVE the problem! This is the first movie I've seen that really conveys the absurdity of petty arguments escalating into gun fights! "Boyz" also says that "We know there is a problem, and here's some suggestions of how to remedy the problem!" No such message is communicated in the knockoffs! The Hughes Brothers (Menace II Society, Dead Presidents) helped the Hood movie make the transition from "Anti-Establishment" to becoming "The Establishment"! The "Stop the Violence" message was transformed into: "Live Fast, Die Young, never outlive your glory." Who cares if your behavior is turning the neighborhood into the OK Corral!Boyz in the Hood is the only movie to introduce you to the genre!

reviews.review_title: All Quiet on the South Central 'Hood
reviews.content: First off, I don't see what's so special about John Singleton.  Spike Lee is miles beyond him in both talent, style, and precision while Singleton lags behind.  2 Fast 2 Furious is concrete evidence that whatever vision he had got smashed up along the way.Enter Boyz N the Hood.  Singleton sets up the film like a bad 1980s drama with a plot concept traceable to All Quiet on the Western Front and even further than that.  Fill in the blanks for the following as you go along.Group of _____ young men, childhood friends, become disillusioned about life after _____.  Survivors learn about _______.Simple chain of events, huh?  The cast is even simpler.  However, kudos to "Larry" Fishburne for personifying philosophy that I'm certain Spike Lee holds in high regard.  Overall, Boyz N the Hood is as predictable and uninspired as the the 'Hood flick.  John Singleton IS overrated.  Stick with Do the Right Thing because it is more willing to understand confrontation than this low-brow stuff. (33%)

reviews.review_title: The importance of a father figure - probably the main point of the film
reviews.content: Being from Australia, my understanding and familiarity with issues of gang violence and south central los angles is fairly limited. While I don't take everything in this film as gospel, it certainly was a thought-provoking and powerful movie.However, I feel that some people misread what the messages of the film were, probably because they had a preconceived idea of the underlying themes that would be self-evident in a film concerning 'the hood.' I felt that it did not particularly deal with, or perhaps, harp on about racism. Instead, it chose to focus on daily life against a backdrop of crime, violence, drug dealing and substance abuse. However, while there is a presumption that such surroundings automatically breads crime and disaster, Singleton didn't shy away from the view that choice survives. Tre is presented at the start of the film as a boy who seems to be encountering behavioural problems at school - perhaps the early indications that he is about to wonder the path leading nowhere.Tre's mother sends him to live with his father - almost as if it's a punishment of sorts. Singleton appears to emphasise that Tre's mother is not going to display a forgiving attitude towards her son's misbehaviour, while reinforcing that her concern for his welfare stems from her love and hopes for a good life. In short - she made a tough choice in the best interests of and out of genuine love and concern for her child. Singleton rightly endorses her as a terrific mother. Tre's father is subsequently introduced early and while he appears to be a comparatively strict parent, you begin to understand what Singleton is really trying to point out: the importance of a male authority figure and role model. Consider it closely and reflect on the various times in the film that an aspect of parenthood is canvassed. Tre's father says to Tre "I'm trying to teach you responsibility" and that his friends don't have anyone to show them importance of taking responsibility for yourself. Namely, they don't have fathers.In the early stages of the film, Doughboy (as a child) is arrested for stealing. At this time, we notice that Doughboy has been raised by a single mother who is portrayed as young and irresponsible, not to mention the fact that she fails to adequately discipline Doughboy or instill a responsible attitude. When the film jumps to stage where they are nearing the end of high school, Doughboy's mother is portrayed as a wiser and sharper women and a more capable parent. If only she'd waited till she was older and wiser before having children. It was interesting to note that Singleton used the character to Ricky to show that not all children of irresponsible parents become criminals. But then again, Singleton wasn't afraid to insert the fact that Ricky - the naturally good son with a more positive attitude and a bright future - also has a child before finishing high school. In fact, Singleton seems to point out his disapproval of young parents several times throughout the film. When we learn that Tre is a virgin because he was afraid of being a father, his reasoning may seem odd to some, but his responsible attitude and "smart choice" ethic starts to become more apparent. This culminates to the end of the film where Tre is forced to make, what may well be, the most serious choice in his life. This is really where Singleton reenforces the need for young men to have a father-figure; a male role model who can teach them to make the right choices. The consciousness and smart-choice attitude is why Tre asked Doughboy to pull over the car and let him out towards the end of the film.Singleton even expresses his view on this subject early in the film. Remember the scene in the first 30 minutes or so where Tre's father and Tre are fishing and he asks Tre "what do you know about sex?" Here, he teaches his child from an early age that "any fool with a dick can make a child, but only a real man can raise his children." It would appear that this was one of the main messages of the film.As well as this, also stand back and consider how Singleton assembles the film. The first section is an insight into the children, their current circumstances and their surroundings. Then, cut to eight years later and here is where they are, now that they are about to enter adulthood. Singleton seems eager to point out this connection between responsible home life/irresponsible home life and how the children of such homes turn out years later. Ironically, Doughboy was being arrested for the first time at the end of the "childhood" section of the film and had just come out of jail (for what was probably his third, fourth, fifth offence?) at the start the "eight years later" section of the film.Downside: I thought this film rose above the "this is all the white man's fault" line, but there was a scene or two where it featured unnecessarily. That wasn't the focal point of the film

reviews.review_title: A powerful and tragic film about the black experience in an American ghetto.
reviews.content: You get a look at 3 kids growing up in South Central Los Angeles. This movie stands atop its genre because it develops all of its central characters, gives us background and depth into their lives, and weaves them into a coming of age story set in a poor and sometimes violent Urban setting. Few films could develop so many characters so astutely, and still tell a compelling story that involves all of them. Beyond the strength of the character development and plot, this film provides a more balanced view of the inner city than any film before it or after it. This is not a movie about clichés, stereotypes, or tired plot devices. This is a story involving a real place and real people. A powerful and tragic film about the black experience in an American ghetto. This is the best of the urban drama/urban crime genre.

reviews.review_title: "Boyz" grow up real fast in the hood
reviews.content: If your first inclination about Boyz n' the Hood is all about being a thug and poppin'caps, be prepared for an education. John Singleton filmed what can be best described as a brief glimpse into hard living in hard times in Compton, CA. It's about surviving the hood, and holding on to the dreams that can get you out.  Whether the vehicle is a football scholarship or a '64 Chevy Impala lowrider, the message isn't about violence, but about peace, and increasing it without ceasing it.  Forget all those rap videos, your true education begins in the school of hard knocks, Professor Singleton's Intro to Reality 101.  This is a film that has you rooted to your seat.  Especially powerful is Lawrence Fishburne telling his son how the real estate interests have no interest in the people except what they can grab from them.  Learn from this film.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of the decade!
reviews.content: John Singleton and Cuba Gooding Jr have never been better than here and Laurence Fishburne is amazing.  At the time it came out, no other film had portrayed the culture of violence in the inner-city ghettos and the devastation that young black men were facing in the 90's.  If you live in the quiet suburbs it's horrifying that in these communities just going to the corner store can result in you being shot down in a hail of bullets. Along with Spike Lee's films, this one brought acclaim to African-American directors and opportunities for others to let their voices be heard.  It is a powerfully emotional film that will live on as one of the best of the decade.

Talk about a gripping tale. I know nothing about LA, other than it is in California – and Cheech Marin wrote a song, 'Born in East LA.' With respect, I have nothing witty or supposedly clever to add to this piece of art – it is just too good to make light of. I do not huddle in poddy-puddles of obsequiousness, nor do I buckle to PC pressure, being forthright and honest tops sycophancy any day. If I felt this was some 'phony' suck-up piece – I would award it a 'Quinton.' It is not. This movie has too much to say, that should be heard; a sense of feeling and familial caring. The depth of each character is well defined, and the cast is outstanding. I really enjoyed the storyline it is a well manufactured piece, brought together by some outstanding directing. I do highly recommend this movie. It speaks volumes and defines a very hard life. Great job...a story that...well...defines itself.

Important, and groundbreaking. In his debut film, John Singleton (just 23 years old) is so honest in the things he examines - violence within the black community, which we see from the very beginning with the little kids, the importance of parenting, gentrification (how fantastic to hear this commented on in 1991!), and how problematic it is to refer to women as b***'s and ho's (say what you will about the sexism a lot of the characters evince). Most importantly, the film seems unwaveringly true to the reality of growing up black in South Central L. A. The parallels in this film to 'Stand By Me' from five years earlier are eerie and disturbing, when you think about how different the worlds are for the white and black kids in the films (and in reality). There are lots of great performances here, including those from Ice Cube, Laurence Fishburne, Cuba Gooding, Jr., and Angela Bassett. The only thing I didn't care for was the soundtrack, whose synth-overtones didn't fit the film very well.

reviews.review_title: A film that isn't afraid to speak the truth and show the truth.
reviews.content: This is a very eye-opening film that won't cower from the harsh realities of a black man's streets. Boyz in the Hood, a break out film for writer and director John Singleton, chronicles the difficult task of black youth trying to climb out of a crime-ridden neighborhood in Los Angeles and their choices. The film vividly and with detail depicts the life of these young black men from different family structures in an inner city community.Three characters illustrate the different life paths taken. Tre' (played by Cuba Gooding Jr.) started out living with his mother Rita (played by Angela Bassett). When he began to get in trouble at school as a teenager, he is to live with his father Furious Styles (played by Lawrence Fishburne). Furious lives in a neighborhood crime and gangs are common. Tre' immediately find two friends who are brothers: Ricky (played by Morris Chestnut) and Doughboy (played by Ice Cube) who are from a single parent home where a father is not present.Although Tre', Ricky, and Doughboy are friends, they each choose a different direction. An example is a scene where after spending time together as friends they each choose to do something different with the rest of their after noon. Tre' goes fishing with his father Furious, Ricky plays with his football, and Doughboy goes to the store. While at the store, Doughboy decides to steal and is taken to juvenile jail. This was the beginning of Doughboy's life of crime and gang activity. In another scene, Ricky has a recruiter from USC visit his home and discuss a possible scholarship if he can obtain the appropriate score on the SAT. Tre' spends a lot of time with Furious and is taught how he will use his intellect to succeed in life.John Singleton uses music, sound, and dialog to bring to life the mood and feel of a crime-ridden neighborhood. The music chosen is reflective of the tenseness and violence of the area. The use of hard-core rap especially in scenes with Doughboy was appropriate setting the tone of the action. A nice contrast was the R&B music during the scenes with Furious and Tre'. Along with the rap music, the dialog adds to the authenticity of the film. While there is cursing throughout the film, it is used in context of what is happening in the scene. Other dialog between Rita and Furious portray the struggle between divorced parents in determining what is best for Tre' and his future. Finally, the use of background sound like gunshots, helicopters, and crying babies add to the overall feel of the film.The shooting of Ricky at the end of the film is similar to the shooting violence in the beginning of another John Singleton film Poetic Justice. Each exposed the agony of young lives cut short by inner city violence. Justice (played by Janet Jackson in Poetic Justice) and Tre' must learn to move forward in their lives and not let the tragedy claim their future.Overall, John Singleton portrayed the difficult choices young black men make everyday to try to escape or survive violence in crime-filled neighborhoods. All through the film, he exposes how the choices made by each young man affect them and their loved ones.
Some good performances (especially Fishburne), some funny and deep moments, but a little too slow and, at times, childish.

reviews.review_title: Boyz n the Hood is a strong directional debut, authentic and brilliant on so many levels
reviews.content: Boyz n the Hood is a hood drama film written and directed by John Singleton in his feature directorial debut. 2015 was the first time I watched this fine movie, truly a work of art that deserved its Oscar nominations. It's one of the most authentic and realistic hood films I have seen, John Singleton tells the story brilliantly and his direction is on the same level as his storytelling skills. The camera work improves as the film goes on but I'm not judging him for that, it's his directional debut after all and I feel like the storytelling and the direction he gave to the actors is more meaningful than camera work. The cinematography is brilliant and beautiful, the imagery is memorable and many scenes are iconic. Maybe it's me loving the film that I recognize the scenes and sets, or it's just brilliant cinematography. Mostly the latter, I think.The case is filled with big names like Cuba Gooding Jr., Ice Cube, Morris Chestnut, Laurence Fishburne, Nia Long, Regina King, and Angela Bassett. The story follows Tre Styles who is sent to live with his father Furious Styles in South Central Los Angeles which is surrounded by the neighborhood's booming gang culture. The film kickstarted the acting careers of Cuba Gooding Jr., Morris Chestnut and Nia Long. For good reasons, talented actors, all of them.John Singleton sadly passed away back in 2019 and since then I have wanted to re-watch this but didn't for some unknown reason, at least I was following Snowfall which I still am and recommend to everyone who are a fan of this film. What is so special about the writing is that Singleton wrote the film based on his own life and that of people he knew and the idea came to him in film school. The United States Library of Congress selected it for preservation in the National Film Registry, I can only say that it has every right to be there. It's an unforgettable experience and an incredible film.

John Singleton creates a very powerful tale of the inner-city black experience. While the film at times pretends that cliched messaging and preaching is somehow high-minded revelations, it doesn't taint the tone or consume much time. The film is not afraid to point out some harsh realities that people don't like to talk about-like the problem of absent fathers and single motherhood in the black community-as well as recognizing the importance of a present, strong, masculine father figure in a young man's upbringing. It shows how easy people can get sucked into a bad life and how hard it is to resist the pull of crime, poverty, and prison. While the film focuses primarily on the film's protagonist Tre, it devotes sufficient time to character development so that the viewer is able to get invested in each character and their motivations and struggles. Overall, very well done.

reviews.review_title: RAISES YOUR VIEW OF THA HOOD!!!
reviews.content:
This movie has been slammed for doing a good job, the view it paints is a realistic one and people hate having to face a truth as harsh as this. 
Singleton's directorial debut is laced with racism, deep brooding racism, that inhabits almost all his characters and this stems probably from personal experience but it's quite real onscreen.  Furious Styles is an unusual " on hands Black father" who imbues his only son with the strength and dignity of his kind.  Weaning his kid away from the streets is difficult and is one seeming losing battle. But Tre comes in time to appreciate the values being passed on to him by his dad. As Furious tells Tre "I didn't raise you to lose you to the streets".  
In contrast, we have Doughboy who lives on the streets by his own rules, not relating to his mother who obviously means him well, his brother Ricky who happens to be the "golden boy" and apple of Mama's eye, this is an entirely different tangent and he tries to draw Ricky into the seedier aspects of street life, Ricky keeps resisting but eventually becomes caught in the resultant violence of his brother's reputation.  Cuba Gooding Jnr as Tre fights again and again to escape the soft boy image cast on him by his doting dad and this almost destroys him. 
Singleton's imagery is sharp, unflattering and healthy.  His direction is swift, paced and unrelenting.One of the most poignant scenes is toward the end when Doughboy hears Tre is going to college after Ricky's shooting,  there is a kind of desolation in his face as if he knows he's lost the battle.  The camera pans onto his face for a split second and holds briefly but it seems like forever and forever actually flashes through his face but then it's gone and he's back to being Doughboy who doesn't last much longer.  A Frightening Look At Street Life.  10/10

This movie is the GREAT AMERICAN TRAGEDY of our times. I remember once reading that in true tragedy you don't cry when the hero meets his tragic end. I didn't understand why I was crying at the opening scene where small children view the outline of a murdered body on their way to school. But I didn't cry at the tragic end -- it was inevitable and I was numb. The great american tragedy is not about powerful corporate giants. It's about those children who are too used to seeing death and crime scenes on their way to school.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of the '90s
reviews.content: Boyz n the Hood tells the story of three young kids in South Central Los Angeles and their experiences trying to survive the streets. The central character is Tre Styles, who is sent to South Central at ten by his mom and gets raised by his father "Furious." Tre, along with his friend Ricky, grew up to be pretty innocent young adults, staying out of trouble and not getting shot. They were experiencing the average teenage things: hanging out with friends, getting girls, and worrying about their futures. Ricky was in line for a football scholarship at USC and Tre was on his way out of the "hood." However, like so many black men before him, Ricky had his dreams shattered due to gang violence and he was brutally murdered. The movie is most importantly a social commentary on the status of African-Americans in our country. They have all lived out of fear of each other and not just of other races. Ever since the Civil Rights Movement, African-Americans have lived in fear of the establishment, thinking that something might happen again. The anger of the black masses seen from afar is the anger of being persecuted for so many years previously and now they were venting their anger with their newfound freedom. This is what the movie portrays so well.This is one of the most emotionally powerful movies of the 90's and it is relatable to all kinds of people. African-Americans saw this movie as their experience while white people were able to see what was going on in the inner cities. This is probably one of the best debuts ever by any filmmaker and John Singleton, who had just graduated from USC film school, became the youngest director at 24 years of age to be nominated for an Academy Award. It can be seen throughout the movie that Singleton was very passionate about the material and it rubbed off on all of the actors, who played their parts perfectly. Most notable among the cast were Cuba Gooding Jr. and Laurence Fishburne as Tre and Furious Styles. Both delivered highly believable and gut-wrenching performances that stick with the audience long after the credits roll. This is one of the most real and powerful movies of the last quarter-century and it almost single-handedly increased African-American jobs in the film industry exponentially.

Boyz n the Hood relies on a well written and interesting script that raises many questions. The movie though seems a bit edulcorated, the violence being more suggested than shown on screen, even when you consider Singleton tried to portray his own experience in the hood. The film is also a bit lengthy at moments whereas some themes could have been more developed.The characters are a bit flat but Gooding Jr. and particularly Fishburn stood out acting-wise.As for the cinematography, it is muddled and tentative, you can clearly see that it is Singleton's directional debut.

This is a great point that Singleton took time to illustrate since the majority of men in the black community are often raised by their single mothers. The principles that Furious (Played by Larry Fishborne) install in Trey (Played By Cuba Gooding Jr.)are something not portrayed in mainstream movies. Singleton carefully weaves this into every day life experienced in the lower income black community, drugs, gang activity, violence, & the general feeling of hopelessness. reviews.review_title: Entertaining and hard-hitting: everyone should see this film.
reviews.content: I watched 'Boyz n the Hood' for the first time yesterday, and it was everything I hoped it would be: powerful, yet touching, and bleak, while offering solutions and hope for the future. Fifteen years on, this film still has hugely important things to say, and unfortunately, not just for America. The emergence of black on black gun violence in Britain is a worrying trend of recent years. While it should not be exaggerated, there's no doubt that issues raised in this film apply equally to the British case (for example, the two innocent Birmingham girls caught in the crossfire on New Years Eve two years ago). The culture of 'respect' as the cause of needless young deaths is a key part of 'Boyz n the Hood's message. Furthermore, John Singleton's presses home his central point, that the black community needs strong male role models, with force and clarity. Furious Styles (played brilliantly by Laurence Fishburne) is clearly the type of figure Singleton wishes there were more of. He is ultimately powerless in the face of other strong influences determining Tre's actions. However, at a crucial moment in the film's climax, it is proved that his job as a father has already been done.

reviews.review_title: One of the most important films ever made.
reviews.content:
I watched this movie the other night because I had not watched it in a long time. It was on TBS a few weeks ago, but I never like to watch films like this that are edited. So, I rented it and watched it.Here's the deal. I remember watching this movie as a 18 year old. Seeing it from an 18 year old's perspective, this was one of the most intense movies I had ever seen. After watching it the other night, I would say that it is not the most intense film I have seen, but it is one of the most important films to have ever been made.First, it was the first film of its' kind to reveal to the world what was going on in South Central and other places like it. For someone like me, a kid who grew up in a loving home with both parents in a suburban town, this movie was and still is an eye-opener. The "shock factor" the film had when it was released in 1991 is not their anymore, simply because the world now knows what is going on in places like SC. But at the time, the film broke the wall down to a world that needed to see what was going on. For that, you have to give John Singleton props. What I like most about the film is the fact that Singleton does not hold back. The reality that is "the hood" is presented without any attempt to sugarcoat it. And that is the way it needed to be. Some of Singleton's views expressed in the film are debatable, and I found myself not always agreeing with some of these views. Nevertheless, I would not have had Singleton change a thing about the movie. I'm sure their are people who are like Furious, Doughboy, and Tre and share the views each character had.
When you watch the film now, try and remember that things were different in 1991. Appreciate the film for what it meant to audiences back then. Still, the message Singleton wanted to express still stands true today. At the end, you see the words "Increase The Peace". To me, Singleton wanted the world to know what was going on in places like South Central, and he wanted people to come together and stop the unneccassary violence. If only it were that simple.

reviews.review_title: The biggest wake up call in movie history.
reviews.content: During the early 90s, there's was a huge exposure of issues in the black community through cinema and music, Boyz N Da Hood, along with Colors (released in the late 80s.) and Menace II society, provided white America a glimpse into the social problems of the race they had long tortured and harassed. It was also during this time that the LA riots happened, further escalating awareness in the social and economic problems in areas like South Central LA. But to me, the biggest wake up call of them all, next to the riots, was Boyz N Da Hood.From its disturbing opening, to its tragic end, Boyz N Da Hood serves as a look into the dark side of Los Angeles. Filled with tremendous acting from actors destined for stardom, such as Ice Cube, in his brilliant acting debut, as Doughboy, Cubba Gooding Jr. as Tre and Lawrence Fishburne as Tre's father 'Furious'. It explores a part in the world where the Innocent are killed for no reason, Crooked racist cops roam the streets and helicopters and gun shots are heard night after night. It explores themes like racism, gang violence, gentrification, bad law enforcement and having a strong father figure for young black males in urban city communities. This is the kind of movie that comes around once in a generation.My views on towards American life and Los Angeles were never the same. The one thing that saddens me the most is that when your modern day teenager watches this movie, they think its cool to walk around with a pistol, pull drive bys on innocent people, call women 'bitches' and 'hos' and kill people for messing with you.As the end credits say, we have to "Increase the peace."

Boyz n the Hood is an important work.  It is essentially the sociological meditations of writer/director John Singleton, with a decent plot mixed in. In particular, the scene in which Tre's friend is brought home shot to the shock and horror of his family is surreal and moving.While not deserving of its high level of critical acclaim, Boyz n the Hood is a must-see.  It was ground-breaking in its frank depiction of the much-ignored (at the time) suburban ghettos and their disadvantaged inhabitants.  But as far as classic African-American films are concerned, Spike Lee's Do the Right Thing is a much better work.
