reviews.review_title: A compelling yet tragic story about real life in the hood.
reviews.content: Boyz n the Hood is a story about a boy named Tre Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr.) who grows up in the ghetto of L.A. Tre is sent to live with his father, Furious Styles (Laurence Fishburne), and ends up becoming best friends with two brothers, Ricky and Doughboy. Furious quickly learns the struggles of raising his son in a neighborhood surrounded with drugs, alcohol, and murder. Boyz n the Hood shows that having a father figure is essential to how a young boy matures and turns into a man. It shows the importance of having a male role model and how that can affect a boy's life decisions as he grows into the man he will become.The importance of having a father figure is shown throughout the film by the choices that Tre makes. Tre and Ricky try to do the right things and be respectful young men. However, just being in the same crowd as Doughboy and his friends brings unexpected trials. Ricky and Doughboy do not have a father figure in their lives. Doughboy is seen as a lazy, ignorant criminal to his mother while Ricky is the perfect child. Because of this favoritism, Doughboy ends up in jail and lives a reckless lifestyle while Ricky pursues a college football career.Even though Tre was surrounded by a neighborhood with unfortunate circumstances, he continued to uphold the morals his father had taught him. He develops a loving friendship with and a deep respect for his father. Because of his father's constant encouragement and direction, Tre is able to avoid many of the problems that his closest friends are facing. The frustrations of living in a neighborhood surrounded by violence, poverty, and drug and alcohol abuse overwhelm Tre at times, which is shown through his emotional responses.The setting of this film is a very important contributor to the main theme. The neighborhood in which the movie was filmed shows the hardships of living in the ghetto. In order to show how important his relationship was with his father, the setting needed to be in a rough area. Also, the dialogue contributes greatly to the theme. The dialogue between the characters consists mainly of profanity to show how people in the hood talk to one another. Another film that has a similar theme to Boyz n the Hood is Dead Homiez. Also filmed in L.A., Dead Homiez shows how African American families and their friends are affected by violence in their community.There is a strong moral message concerning father figures and life choices that is conveyed through the theme of Boyz n the Hood and it should not be ignored.

reviews.review_title: Boyz N the Hood is the story of a young man's journey of growing up in the "hood".
reviews.content: Boyz N the Hood is the story of a young man's journey of growing up in the "hood". Director John Singleton portrayed Tre Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr.), journey, along with two childhood friends, Doughboy (Ice Cube) and Ricky Baker (Martin Chesnut) as an exciting but to also show the social issues of young African-American males. Tre is highly intelligent but with a bad temper. His father Jason "furious" Styles, taught him how to take responsibility for his actions, to be a leader, and to determine what's right and wrong in any given situation. Doughboy is the exact opposite. Doughboy chose the life of drugs, alcohol, and violence, but still has pride and honor in himself, friends, and family, even though his mother was obvious that she did not appreciate or favor him. Ricky Baker, who is Doughboy's half brother, the All-American athlete. He is hoping to win a football scholarship to attend college, and his mother could see great things in him. Although he had a child at a young age, he strives to do anything to better himself for his son.The story revolves around Tre, and his journey from childhood to manhood. He grew in the inner city of Los Angeles, and the story starts out as Tre as a kid, displaying his intelligence and also his short temper. His mother sends him off to live with his father, to show him how to be a man. His father is hard on him, with many chores and restrictions, but it's only to show him what responsibility is. Throughout his journey, he meets a woman, Brandi (Nia Long) and falls in love with her. He always goes to her when he's seen danger, especially when an African-American police officer puts a gun to his neck for no reason at all.The dialog of this film plays a key role in presenting the theme of a young man's trials of growing up in the "hood". The slang language, the threats of violence, young love, and pain is presented by the dialog throughout this film. Listening to the dialog in this movie, the viewer can sense the journey Tre went on to becoming a man. The events that he has witnessed and his thoughts and feelings are portrayed throughout the film. The lighting of the film also creates the mood for different scenes throughout this film. The low lighting or almost dark scenes created the dramatic and intense scenes that were in the film. Such as when the African-American police officer held a gun to Tre's throat had dark lighting, and created a powerful scene. This film has many strong scenes with low or even dark lighting to enhance the feelings of the viewers. The director wanted the viewers to feel as if they were a part of the movie, and also that this was the reality of young men living in the inner cities. Using different lighting techniques portrayed this thought exceptionally.Sharing the same general theme of a young man's journey through life and the trials and tribulations that African-American males go through, is the film Ballast. This movie follows the lives of a single mother and her son living in one of the poorest parts of America. After extremes trials, the fragile family grows together. This movie is very similar to Boyz N the Hood in the general theme of the movie. Tre's journey through his childhood represents every young African-American male growing up in the inner cities of America. Throughout his journey, Tre's has seen death, fell in love, and witnessed pain and suffering and is determined not to become like others in the hood.

I will be reviewing Boyz n the Hood directed and written by John Singleton. The movie has a few recognizable names, first there is Ice Cube, Angela Bassett, Nia Long, and Laurence Fishburne. The selection really helped bring the movie to life, and I think all did a awesome job of portraying the films theme of gangs, drugs, and violence in inner city kids. The film is primarily focused around three boys who are growing up in Los Angeles, where they all have different paths, yet were all friends. Ricky is an athlete trying to get a college scholarship to play football, Trey also is a young man trying to get out of the "ghetto" and attend college, and dough boy, who is the one wrapped up in the wrong crowd of violence, gangs, and drugs. Another huge part of the film is Trey's father, who is trying to teach him the right path to follow.During the movie there are some major points of lows and highs for the boys. They face huge decisions on whether or not to continue on the right path, or to succumb to the violence that is inevitably their fate. When Trey makes a decision not to be involved on the attack against gang members who have wronged him, it starts to turn the movie around that, no matter your surroundings, you can still make choices to better yourself and remover yourself from the situations. The movie is very powerful and involves lots of violence, but the story seems to portray a good idea of what inner city kids have to deal with growing up, and the different paths they must choose, or in some instances we saw in the movie, they do not even have to be choosing the wrong path, for it to sneak up on them and cause harm. That is a very exciting feeling, knowing that you may start off in a very bad place, but with consistency, and hard work, you can really be anything you want to be.

reviews.review_title: A True, Political Message for Everyone in Society
reviews.content: In essence, a work of art. Circulating around real life issues and exploring deeper the misunderstood nature of black lives and their so-called 'brotherhood'. The film itself is slow-paced, gradually progressing and developing into transition. Captivating the vulnerability and fear that many black lives experience even today - which is why the film is so very significant and educational. The watch begins in 1984, a young Tre Styles is excluded from school due to bad behaviour and his mother makes him live with his father, nicknamed 'furious' and portrayed by Laurence Fishbourne. 'Furious' is a wise, working man who teaches his son respect and basic life manners. Tre goes out in the street with his three friends Ricky, Chris and Doughboy (also black) and find a dead human body, the four are confronted by an intimidating older group of boys who steal Ricky's ball, Doughboy demands for it back but is beaten and kicked. Furious and Tre go fishing the next day, Tre's father encourages his son not to join the army after explaining to him about the Vietnam war. Upon returning home, Tre and Furious see Chris and Doughboy arrested for shoplifting. In 1991, a barbecue takes place in celebration to Doughboy's recent release. The schoolboys now young adults sees Chris in a wheelchair paralysed due to multiple gun shot wounds and two new friends join the initial four, Dooky and Monster. Ricky is a top-student at his high school, aiming for a successful career manifested by his academic achievements, he, who lives with his single mother Brenda, girlfriend Shanice and infant son, explains that he needs at least 700 in his SAT's in order to get into his desired college. Tre is an intelligent teenager who works at a clothing shop and has a devout catholic girlfriend, Brandi, who is set to have sex after marriage, much to Tre's frustration. On the night that Ricky and Tre finish their SAT's exams, they join in on a street racing gathering, Ricky is rudely bumped into by a group of 'thugs' who engage in an argument, Doughboy brandishes out a handgun causing the group of rival attendees all dressed in red to vanish. Moments later the rival attendee fires a sub machine gun into the air, causing chaos and commotion in the street. During their exit from Los Angeles, the group are pulled over by the police, the lead officer is recognised by Tre as the same who came calling 7 years ago after a burglary took place at Furious' home - he intimidates the group and threatens Tre with a gun, assuming that they provoked the shooting. Tre shows up at Brandi's home and breaks down in front of her, the pair go inside and have sex for the first time. The next day, Doughboy and Ricky get into a fight that Brenda and Tre break up. Tre takes Ricky on a walk through the neighbourhood to cool down and the pair spot the rivalling gang from last night in a car. The two protagonists sprint away attempting to avoid any conflict; Dooky, Doughboy and Monster sense danger when seeing their two friends sprinting, Ricky fails to keep up with Tre and is greeted by the driving gang, the leader winds down his window and shoots Ricky twice before driving away. Hysterical, Tre holds Ricky as he slowly dies and Doughboy turns up with the others to visualise the tragedy. They take Ricky's corpse to his home where Shanice and Brenda emotionally blame Doughboy who unsuccessfully tries to convince them that it wasn't his fault. That night, a distraught Brenda sadly opens Ricky's exam results to find out he got 710, more than enough to have got him into college. Outraged, Tre takes his fathers handgun and intends to exact revenge, Furious encourages Tre to abandon the thought of revenge but his son ignores him and leaves out the back window to join Doughboy, Dooky and Monster. Tre soon realises that revenge isn't going to solve any of his issues and only add to the problem, he evacuates the plan and returns home, he and Furious both don't say a word and walk to their respective rooms. Doughboy and his two friends identify the rival group at a fast food outside eating area, the group realise their targeting and attempt to escape but Doughboy kills two of them and wounds their leader, Ferris with an AK-47, Doughboy exits the car and confronts Ferris who states he didn't kill Ricky and insults him, Doughboy shoots him twice, killing him. The next day, Doughboy visits Tre and understands his reasons for leaving. Doughboy knows that he will sooner or later face retaliation for the murder he committed the previous evening and accepts the consequences of his crime-ridden lifestyle. He plaintively questions why America does not care about the life in the ghetto, and sorrowfully notes he has no family after Ricky's death and Brenda's disowning of him. Tre embraces him and tells Doughboy he has a brother in him. The epilogue reveals that Doughboy saw Ricky buried the next day and was himself murdered two weeks later. Tre and Brandi attend Morehouse and Spelman colleges in Atlanta, respectively. A film so topical and relevant to the present day, an often misunderstood subject regarding the livelihoods of black lives and the stereotypes that accompany their existence. The title itself is significant, including language common to black people in the 90s, the hood being a neighbourhood dedicated to black people and boys spelt purposely with a 'z' emphasises a typical rebellious nature. The focus that the film centres around is the idea of unity and togetherness amongst black people, and that they should help and protect one another in order to 'prove' their place in society. Fishburne's character is the mouthpiece manifesting this ideology; notably when demanding Tre not to take revenge, Furious believes killing another black man as revenge only adds to America's problem and gives the ignorant racists a reason to question black lives' presence. A sad, emotionally moving watch that portrays the harsh reality of racial injustice.

reviews.review_title: One of the best of the 90's and maybe one of the best of all time.
reviews.content: First thing's first, this movie -could- easily have come off as too self-important and pretentious, had just about everything on the producers side not been crafted, and thought out so meticulously.Everything from the casting, to the setting, to near perfect introduction of a relatively high number of character's who are all given adequate screentime to get to know them as much as we should.All of the performances are brilliant, and I'm so glad this immortalized Ice Cube as not just one of the most iconic rapper/writers to a very well established actor. Recently rewatched it, understood it better and enjoyed it far more.I seriously think this may be one of the greatest movies of all time, sort of the 'Rebel Without A Cause' of the 1990's.

Boyz N The Hood is a film about several young black children coming of age while growing up in the ghetto. Furious played by Laurence Fishburne is trying to raise his son Tre' and show him that there is a better way of life and there is a world outside of the Ghetto. Tre' coming of age experiences life in the ghetto and its harsh reality of drugs, prison, poverty and death. Ricky played by Morris Chestnut is on his way to college by way of a sports scholarship for playing football. Ricky is interviewed by college scouts and his future looks bright until Ricky has a confrontation with some gang members that didn't like his brother. Ricky was gunned down in an alley on his way home from the local convenience store. Tre distraught goes home and locates his father's gun and attempts to flee the house with it when Furious takes the gun from Tre's hand and tries to talk some sense into him. Tre then goes to his room and flees through a window where he meets up with Ricky's brother Dough Boy played by Ice Cube. Dough Boy is a young man involved in gang life that gets released from prison but doesn't become a very productive member of society. Dough boy and his crew along with Tre set out to get revenge on the people who killed Ricky. Driving through the city trying to find the men who murdered Ricky Tre asks Dough Boy to stop the car and let him out. Dough boy and his crew continue searching the city till they locate the blood gang member known as Ferris and kill him in retaliation for killing Ricky. This is a film that many people living in the ghetto and poverty can relate to. Furious was the only father figure in the movie, and when Furious found out Tre was getting in trouble in school he told Tre's mother to let Tre live with him. Furious knew that Tre needed a father figure in his life if he was going to have any chances of Tre staying out of trouble and being a positive member of society. This movie is a great example of things that some people from different walks of life would never experience or see for themselves.

Based on the title, one would assume that "Boyz in the Hood" is yet another film glorifying violence on the streets. Quite the contrary, Boyz in the Hood takes a unique look at the lives of three young black men living in the violent streets of Los Angeles, CA. Director John Singleton delivers a riveting, raw, and emotional view about growing up chronicling the lives of three young friends as they navigate through poverty, gang violence, and drugs. The tried but true "Coming of Age" theme is given a fresh perspective as childhood friends Tre Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr.), Doughboy (Ice cube), and Ricky Baker (Morris Chestnut) transcend adolescence and become young men.This film shows the importance of choices and how they can impact the rest of your life and the lives around you. It also reinforces how important positive role models can help an individual in making these choices. A common theme that revolves around other films such as "Menace to Society" (Directors: Albert Hughes, Allen Hughes). This is shown by how different the lives of each of the friends turn out after they grow up approaching the end of high school. Tre, who raised by his father, Furious Styles (Lawrence Fishburne) grows up in a disciplined household. Furious makes sure Tre is accountable for his actions and fully understands the consequences of making the wrong choices. Doughboy, who has recently come home from incarceration, hangs out with his friends and deals drugs. Ricky, who sees playing football as his salvation takes to the sport and aspires to attend college making football his career. All three live in the same rough environment but lead different lives which are influenced by their role models (or lack there of) and through the choices they make.Rather than relying fancy effects or studio sets, Mr. Singleton maintains the feeling of this urban environment by filming in the very locations that he refers to in the film. Filmed on location in Crenshaw Boulevard, Inglewood, and downtown Los Angeles, CA, Mr. Singleton further adds to the depth of his film by bringing viewer into this austere environment. An effect that would not be able to be reproduced in a studio set with props.This is a powerful film is not your typical "Coming of Age" movie and tackles additional problems that may not be faced by all youth growing up. Social awareness is the key to such issues as poverty, drugs, and violence which Mr. Singleton successfully ties together with the lives of three young men as they struggle through life with a common theme that everyone can relate to.

reviews.review_title: Urban coming of age dramatic film about life in the hood.
reviews.content: This film takes place is Los Angeles in the early 1990's during a time of civil unrest and frequent Police brutality. The main character's first appear as adolescent kids when they are exposed to the everyday struggle of crime in any forgotten urban community. Dead bodies, whose arms are prodded with needles, lay about. The crime rate is evident by the cars on the block that sit with broken windows. Many are damaged by fire, yet they have not been removed and are now used as jungle gyms along with discarded old bed mattresses.These kids are forced to occupy their time with whatever entertainment they can think of, so of course they turn "narcoleptic"... soon stealing in the streets leads to time in jail at early ages for characters like Ice Cube's Doughboy who eventually serves several years in juvenile detention for general gang-banging. Other characters of the movie like Chris, actor Reggie Green are victims of gang violence and as a result are portrayed as adult quadriplegics. These depictions ring true in many communities as what you put into life is ultimately what you get out of it.This movie also depicts what it's like to be from the same area as a gang-banger, and not fall into to the traps facing urban at-risk youth. Cuba Gooding's character Tre Styles is forced to make several life changing decisions, from not having unprotected sex, with Brandi played by actress Nia Long, to hanging out late into the evening. Tre is also aware of ongoing gang wars amongst him and his childhood homeys. Unlike his peers, Tre has a male role model or "father" that is guiding him through the mean streets of LA, played by actor Laurence Fishburne.Ricky Carter (Morris Chestnutt), brother of Ice Cube's character Doughboy is facing peer pressing decisions that every sexually active high school teenager faces during an unplanned pregnancy. Ricky Carter can either sign scholarship papers, and play football or stay home and raise his child that is soon to be. While dealing with the issues of his life, Ricky is caught up in random gang violence, falls victim to gun fire leaving the future of his family uncertain.Boyz n the Hood did an excellent job at telling the story of every urban community in America that is stuck in gang warfare. Decisions have to be made every day of which way to survive and how not to fall prey to those who have grown hopeless to different issues including waking waking up that morning.

reviews.review_title: Just seen the movie for a film class.
reviews.content: The movie Boyz in the Hood is movie that gives a shocking glimpse into a world of crime, violence, drugs, gangs, and sex in the mean streets of Los Angeles, California. When the movie was released in 1991 it was nominated for two Academy awards for Best Director, and Best Original Screenplay. The movie was written and directed by John Singleton. John Singleton was the first African American and youngest person to ever be nominated for an Academy Award.The cast of actors in the movie Boyz in the Hood include Cuba Gooding Jr., Ice Cube, Laurence Fishburne, Morris Chestnut, Nia Long, Angela Basset, and Regina King.The movie's theme is about the high rates of murder and killing among African American males. The beginning of the movie shows a message that, "One out of every twenty-one Black American males will be murdered in their lifetime." It also shows, "Most will die at the hands of another Black male." The movie uses normal camera angles and lighting.The movie follows the life of three young boys growing up in the south central area of Los Angeles. Tre Styles moves into the Crenshaw area soon after getting in trouble at school. His mother sends him to live with his father to show him how to be a man. Tre has two friends that live across the street from his father named Ricky, and Doughboy. Ricky and Doughboy are half brothers that live with their mother. Tre's father starts teaching him life lessons soon after he arrives to life with him. Tre's father is named Furious Styles. Furious wants his son to learn about how hard work and living up to responsibilities is never easy, but necessary if he does not want to end up dead or imprisoned for crime.The movie soon jumps forward seven years to a welcome home party for Doughboy who recently was released from prison. At the Party is all the local kids including Tre, and Ricky. It shows how Tre has been doing well in school and working a job as well. Then it shows Ricky who has a young baby and girlfriend both living with his mother. The movie later shows Ricky getting interviewed for a football scholarship to play at USC. The movie later shows Ricky and Tre taking the SAT test and how Ricky is struggling with the test. Ricky needs to score a 700 to be eligible to play football at college and is unsure he will score well enough. Tre is involved with a girlfriend and both have been dating for a long time. They are both focused on their futures and college however Tre wants to have sex. After many attempts they engage in a sexual encounter. Ricky has made an enemy from a rival gang of his brother's. Ricky's nemesis chases in down an alley and guns him down in cold blood. Tre witnesses his friend's death and is angered and wants to take revenge. Doughboy and Tre leave together to look for the murder and Tre later gets cold feet and decides he should not be there and is dropped off. Doughboy finds his brother's murder and kills him. The next day Tre and Doughboy discuss their feelings for missing Ricky and Doughboy states how you never know you will get murdered. Then after they finish text states, "Doughboy is later murder himself". The ending shows Tre achieving his dreaming of going to college and leaving the hood.The ending of the movie emphasizes the theme of the movie how dangerous the lives of black men in America can be. It is to help raise awareness to the public about the hardships poor people in many places in America endure. The movie also shows that if people do the right thing and stay away from crime and gangs they can be successful with hard work and determination.

reviews.review_title: Film featuring Black on Black Crime
reviews.content: Boyz N the hood was one of the first movies that told the story of how gang violence was in south central Los Angeles California. Majority of the black males in the community never make it to the age of 21. The main problem was most of these young men were killed by gun violence at the hands of other black males. This movie first debuted in 1991 and had two Academy Award nominations for Best Original Screen Play and Best Director, John Singleton. Mr. Singleton was the first and youngest black director to have an Academy Award nomination.The theme of the movie is how that black males are being exterminated through astronomical rates in the inner city. There are no special camera angles or lightening throughout the film. Tre Styles played by Cuba Gooding Jr. was one of the main characters; his mother decides that since he is an influential teenager that it would be better if he was raised by his father. He has two best friends, Ricky played by Morris Chestnut and Doughboy played by Ice Cube. The film follows Tre and his best friends on their adventure through the mean streets of Crenshaw, in south central LA. Tre is taught from his father played by Lawrence Fishburne "How to be a man". These life lessons are essentially necessary so he won't end up dead or in jail. There is a transition in the film when it moves forward seven years to when Doughboy is recently released from being incarcerated. There is a party that is being thrown for him and in one particular scene it shows how Tre is continuing to live his life as a good student and he even has a job, it is also shown that Ricky has a young child and is struggling to get a certain score on the SAT's in order for him to go to USC and play football. While Doughboy was in jail, Ricky got into an altercation with a gang member from another turf because of Doughboy, it later shows Ricky walking down the street and he sees the gang member's car, he tries to run away but is shot in the back in an alley; his death is witnessed by Tre. Tre he is upset and wants revenge, he rides out with Doughboy to find the killer but get scared and he is let out of the car. Doughboy gets revenge by killing the gang member that killed his brother. During the end it states that "Doughboy is later murdered himself". Tre finally achieves his goal of getting out of the hood and going to college. This movie shows how hard it is for young black men to grow up in the hood, and that even if you are trying to live your life right you can still be hurt from someone else's' action, regardless if you were the cause of the problem or not. It also shows that there are some black men that are able to get out of the hood.
The Characters are Rich, and well thought out. Even if there could be some more development with some of the characters, it's a film that's striking and heartfelt.

Everyone I have talked to who has seen this movie says the same thing; "That was a really good movie!". It is much more. Entertainment value= 4 stars. ( No slow parts) Acting= 4 stars. (Fishburne, Cuba, Ice Cube, are truly excellent) Story= 4 stars (Its like a great tragic play) Direction= 4 stars (Singleton I'm sure is proud of this great film) I will always laugh hysterically at the Academy of Motion Pictures lack of integrity for not even nominating this movie for Best Picture. If this story was adapted to Victorian England, it would have swept Best Film, Best Director, and possibly an Oscar for Fish or Cuba. Oh well. I'm betting if you see this movie once, you'll want to see it again.

The movie's plot is about three friends who grow up in the inner city in Los Angeles, California. Singleton manages to portray a microcosm of the harsh realities of the inner city as opposed to the rest of the city.The movie begins with Tre Styles as a boy. His parents are divorced. Tre starts to become troublesome so at the age of ten, his mother sends him to live with his father, Furious in South Central. The story then skips ahead seven years. Furious has successfully taught Tre how to survive, be a man, have pride, and respect. He doesn't want him to be just another statistic. Ricky is an athlete that wants to get out of the hood through athletics. He wants to overcome the violence and pettiness of the gangster way of life. On the other hand, doughboy willfully succumbs to a mentality that respects the hood way of life. He doesn't really try to overcome he just wants to survive. He accepts the idea of drugs, gangs, and violence.Tre is lucky in that his dad, Furious, is his guide in navigating through the on-going cycle of violence. Tre has more reassurance in a better way of life. Then when Tre is about to graduate from High School, his friend is shot and killed. Tre wants to get revenge so he has to decide what decision to make to get even but to avoid ruining the rest of his life. The theme of the movie is based on the notion that if you choose to make the right decisions by elevating your mind you can better your life even though the odds are against you.In the 90s there were similar movies with this same theme, Above The Rim, Juice, and Menace II Society, just to name a few.Some of the motifs used throughout the movie are the constant sounds of police, negative news of violence, police helicopters, and gangsters. The camera angles are in your face and help viewers feel that they are right there with the actors in their life experiencing all of their emotions. You can clearly see the fear, anger, or sadness in the faces of the actors. Despite the harsh reality and gritty storyline, the movie ends with a hopeful message that there are ways to make it out of the hood and all its trappings.

reviews.review_title: Best look at the hood to date
reviews.content: Spoilers WithinI have just finished watching the anniversary edition DVD of this movie, and it just reminded me how good this movie really is.  It's kind of a weird thing to call this new release an anniversary edition, but maybe they'll start a trend of having a 12 year anniversary edition for other movies. Whatever happened to a 10 year edition?  Oh well, enough of that.Boyz n The Hood is John Singleton's 1st movie, and easily his best. Sometimes I see a John Singleton movie, and wonder how this is the same man that created Boyz N The Hood.  Baby Boy didn't impress me all that much, it just seemed too cliched.  The score, the acting, and the character development in Boyz is amazing.  Considering that Ice Cube was in his 1st role, Cuba's performance put him on the map, Morris Chestnut also in his 1st role, and Fishburne was perfect as a father figure. Such great performances from new (at the time) faces.  Who knows if we would have had movies like Friday and Barbershop if Ice Cube were never in this movie.  Who knows if Cuba would have won an Oscar for Jerry McGuire, had he not delivered such a quality performance in Boyz.Boyz to me is unrivalled in terms of it genre, not only because it was one of, if not THE, first movie of its kind, but nothing I have seen in the past 12 years is as good.  Menace II Society was close, but other than that, I can't think of any others.  The movie evokes so many emotions.  Sadness, satisfaction, happiness.  Strong sense of sadness is evoked when Ricky is killed.  Because his character was so well developed despite not having that many lines.  And nothing is more satisfying than when Ice Cube and his crew gun down the men that killed Ricky.  The way it was done, was the way that the audience craved to be done.  I know if I had the chance to come face to face with my family members killer, I might do the same thing.  Possibility of going to jail not withstanding.  Singleton just put together the perfect movie to depict his old neighborhood, it's just a shame that none of his recent work is as good as Boyz N The Hood.  If you are a fan of gangster films, or just good movies in general, you will like Boyz N The Hood.

Boyz in Da Hood is a coming of age drama that is based on the early 90's drug and gang warfare scene that took place in South Central Los Angeles. Having said all of that; this is not a film about drugs, gangs, or violence. It is a tale of families, the journey to manhood, and the decisions in life people face that define their path. The film begins with Furious Styles (Lawrence Fishburn) attempting to educate his young nine year old son Trey, (Cuba Gooding Junior). Trey and his father live alone in a neighborhood in Los Angeles with a high drug and crime rate. Furious wants nothing more than to see his son get an education and graduate college. He does not want to see him go down the path of drugs and gangs. Trey has a group of friends that he runs with from a young age; two of these characters are Doughboy (Ice Cube) and Doughboy's brother Ricky. Even from a young age we can tell that these two brothers are very different characters. Doughboy gives off a hardnosed vibe, while Ricky seems to be more athletically gifted and happy to toss around a football. The film later digresses about ten years into the future and the group of boys are now young men. The choices that they made as children are now starting to come to fruition. Doughboy is recently released from jail, Ricky is finishing high school and getting ready to attend college on a football scholarship, and Trey is interested in becoming a man, in more ways than one. One of the themes in this film that we come to realize is that you don't need to be a part of a gang to be a victim of gang violence. Boyz in Da Hood contains a brilliant script, with relevant dialogue that can still be appreciated today over twenty years later. The film was released only a couple of years before the Rodney King riots and could be seen as a prologue to the madness that ensued. I feel that anyone involved in this film wanted the rest of society to see what takes place in a ghetto; from the lowly drug feine to the dirty cop. Four out of a possible four stars.

In John Singleton's 1991 classic "Boyz in the hood" he manages to uncover the hidden uglies in his society of South Central Los Angeles.Boyz in the hood is a movie about life living in the hood, the movie begins with a young Trey Styles who is living with his mom and struggling to stay out of trouble. After Trey gets into an altercation at school resulting in his suspension his mother takes him to live with his father Furious who is a real-estate broker mostly for black owned business. When Trey arrives at his fathers home Furious begins to help his son grow into a man while teaching him many life lessons such as Responsibility and Being a Leader. After Trey returns with Furious after a fishing trip he sees his friends Dough Boy & Chris being arrested for shoplifting from the local corner store, during the night Trey's house is broken into but Furious manages to scare him away after shooting at the intruder. After a long wait for the police to arrive Furious is berated by a police officer who is black for not killing the intruder as he says "would've been one less nigga on the street." After this scene the movie skips 7 years into the future and we are shown a party welcoming Dough boy home from jail after being in and out, Dough Boy's brother Ricky (also one of Trey's close friends) now has a son and lives at home with his mom and girlfriend. Just these few scenes convey John Singleton's message. Dough Boy's character said it the best with one of the famous lines in the movie "I started thinking, man, either they don't know, don't show, or don't care about what's going on in the hood." Many believed that nobody cared about what was going on in the hood that is why John Singleton's movie is so important. So my rating for the movie would be 10/10 Stars this is truly John Singleton's masterpiece.bryan benjamin templeton 2016

reviews.review_title: Possibly the best movie of the decade.
reviews.content: Forget all the negative press that was said about this movie.  "Too violent," "too angry."  Wrong.  This movie is just the way it is. You will learn.  A lot.

I was blown away by this film when I first saw it around the time of its release. It was the second film to really portray the "hood" and L.A. gangs to mainstream America, (the first being "colors")but the first to portray it from the point of view of black people living amongst the danger, hope and despair and it spawned dozens of imitators, but none lived up to the original.It has aged well, and with the exception of the 4 or 5 rather silly, preachy "public service message" type things added in, it still packs quite a punch on many levels.Ice Cube to me was excellent and Morris Chesnut was good as well. Gooding was very believable and this and his "show me the money" character were the high points in what has become a disappointing career to say the least.Fishburne was great as was Angela Basset.*************SPOILERS************** *********************************** ************************************ *********************************** ***********************************personally, I found so many great scenes in this film, but I found the most powerful to be when young Trey and Furious return from their fishing trip to see Doughboy and Lil Chris being taken away in the patrol car with "ooh child" playing in the background.that particular scene has really stayed with me all these years and was quite representative of the unfortunate net young black kids growing up in the inner city find themselves caught in from a young age, both from not having a responsible father figure around, to being immediately put "on the books" of the legal system and "branded" for life.there are too many great lines to recite.that said, I found the scene with the USC recruiter while touching, to be not very authentic. reviews.review_title: Powerful, thoughtful film from first-time director
reviews.content: An exemplary directorial debut from John Singleton, who managed to create an American classic with his first effort. As we follow Tre Styles from childhood toward becoming a young adult (as played  effectively by Cuba Gooding, Jr.), and attempting to dodge, with the cautious guidance of his parents, the many dangers and risks associated with growing up in inner-city America, the sense of ever-present danger and, often, hopelessness associated with attempting to avoid falling into the cracks of society is abundantly clear. In the role of Tre's troubled friend Dough Boy, Ice Cube is something of a revelation, and his balanced performance, alongside Singleton's excellent script, prevent him from becoming merely another gangster caricature. Lawrence Fishburne and Morris Chestnut add further depth to a strong cast. All in all a very real, gritty depiction of the challenges faced at every turn by African American men and women in modern America. The building anger bristling beneath the surface in so many scenes is particularly resonant given the outburst of violence in the Rodney King Riots that took place in the very same city of the story just one year later. The film spawned several 'urban gang flick' imitations in subsequent years, but most glorified violence and placed an emphasis on a loud soundtrack and sexual explicitness at the expense of strong plot-line, good character development and a serious social message. All three are to be found in Boyz N the Hood.

Written from first-hand experience, Boyz N The Hood was an incredible calling card for John Singleton, and it remains his most influential and widely recognised film. It's a fascinating window into South Central LA in the mid-80 and early 90s, when the infamous riots would take place, as well as a searing indictment of gang culture. There's not many big events in the film, with most of the time being spent watching characters chat about things, posture and make wise cracks, but that's actually why the film is so enjoyable. It builds a bond between the characters and the audience, draws you into their lives, and as such you feel something when tragedy occurs. The standout performers are, of course, Cuba Gooding Jnr and Ice Cube, who play very different individuals, with separate goals and aspirations, but has them reuniting when the situation calls for it. Most of the dialogue is profanity filled tirades or insult laden banter, but it also contains a lot of insight into the woes of its characters, ones which many people still face to this day. It's not a black and white story of one side versus the other, but about how a life of gang violence will always lead to disastrous consequences. It's one hell of a debut, and its such a shame that Singleton would never reach such lofty heights in his career again. But if he's remembered for nothing other than this film, that's still a legacy to be proud of.

Sitting down to watch Boyz ‘N the Hood right now feels fitting. I appreciate what it has to say about the struggles of the black community and gentrification. In fact, I’d be lying if I didn’t say that I was a bit choked up when Laurence Fishburne goes on his rant. I wish there was more of that in the film. Sadly, it felt like the rest of the movie was a fairly by-the-numbers story about young people growing up in a dangerous community with a lot of bad influences. Coming-of-age is already a genre that I don’t typically enjoy, and adding in the depressing nature of this particular film, I had a tough time with it. Admittedly, I was emotionally invested in the journey of the characters, and I shed a few tears at one point when tragedy struck. Yet I saw it coming. Every beat of this movie felt like something I’ve seen before in other films, so it was extremely predictable. Many of those movies might have been drawing inspiration from this one, but I just happen to be in a place now where this all seemed rote. I guess at this point I’m looking for a more unique or nuanced approach to these topics, or even films that shine a light on how we can move forward rather than the pessimistic note we are left with here. I can’t deny that Boyz ‘N the Hood is a well-made movie, and I imagine if I saw it back in the early 90s when I was a teen it would have struck a chord with me and shifted my worldview in some way. Seeing it now, I’m simply left wanting something more, and that may be a problem with me and not the movie itself.

In the midst of the up and coming west coast "gangsta" rap music phenomenon that was about to sweep across America is popularity, Boyz in the Hood takes you to the place that these songs are written about.  All people from the suburbs know of South Central LA is what NWA and Snoop Dogg have told you about it in their albums.  Sounds kind of grimy and rugged, but in a cool and tough guy sort of way, right?  John Singleton takes that thought that is bobbing in your head and puts a bullet right through it.  This is a devastating look at what most young men in the Los Angeles ghetto have to deal with on a daily basis.  Just walking from a picnic down the street to your house, not even a block away you have to worry about someone driving by and opening up fire on you.  Not just a couple random shots from a handgun, but from an automatic military rifle, because of course you did something for them to cause this behavior, right? Wrong again, they are shooting at you and trying to end your life because you may be wearing the wrong colors or maybe they just don't like your neighborhood for some unknown reason.  What Singleton does with this movie is great, because up until Boyz in the Hood gang violence was glorified in music.  There is no glorification in this movie at all.  If you come away from watching this movie thinking it is cool to be "hood" or live in the "ghetto" you have to immediately have your head examined, because you have lost your mind.  A harrowing look at not only how violence and gangs have an effect on the people involved in this criminal activity, but also how it effects the people around them, their family and friends.  We get a unique look from all perspectives in this movie.  From the mother and father to the gangbanger and the do good star football player athlete and they are all stuck in the hell they are forced to call home.  There is a very poignant scene at the end of this movie where Dough Boy played by Ice Cube just kind of shakes his head and realizes people get killed every single day in their area and no one will ever hear about it or even know about it.  He is not mad at this realization, he has accepted this fact and has come to terms with it.  Which is sad in its own right.

The film also carries a certain atmosphere, bolstered by its well-polished production values, which give it a kind of timeless quality, which is especially important considering that the issues dealt with in the film are still around today. Ice Cube failed in Anaconda but I gave him another shot in Boyz 'N he Hood. The gang life is not easy and making a movie about it can be even harder, probably not but I wouldn't know. With the title and summary of the movie I knew this could be one of two movies, one, a violent bloodbath of gang violence with obvious characters and little story, or the exact opposite. Boyz 'N the Hood has really good characters, a deep and meaningful story, and a well developed look in the gang life of California. I don't know how accurate this movie is to the gang life in the 1990s but I felt sympathy for all the characters living in that life and it is hard to believe people actually live like that in real life.
	The story follows the life of Tre, a really intelligent, black, man struggling with the life he lives in. Lawrence Fishburne plays Tre's father and he is an incredible character. I will start this review praising his awesomeness and knowledge of the real world. He is a man who understands the life he lives in and he does not want that for his son. From a very young age he teaches his son how to be a man and how to avoid the life. He is a great role model for his son and brings a lot of depth to the movie. 
There is a scene when he prevents gang violence and goes on a rant about why the hood is the hood. He says something along the lines on the government wants blacks to kill each other. On every corner of the ghetto there is a liquor store and a gun store. That is the true meaning of the movie, or the deeper meaning. Gang violence destroys people's lives and it is pointless. The movie exaggerates how the gangs know it is pointless but they do it because they have to. Ice Cube's character hits on this point too, being the gangster of the movie and the head of his own crew. Its characters like Tre and Ricky which give people hope.
Fishburne and Ice Cube did fantastic in the roles they were given. They went above and beyond and put more than 100% in their performance but Cuba Gooding Jr. plays Tre as an adult and he was underwhelming. I'm not the biggest fan of Cuba Gooding Jr. I don't think he is a great actor but I think he was a good choice for the role. Tre seemed almost unimportant and I don't think it was because of how the story was written, I believe it was because of how he was acted. Tre is different. He doesn't want to live the thug life. He wants to be a success and movie out of the hood. Gooding Jr. didn't act that out so well. His character was boring at times and it took all the way to the end to get any emotion out of him. I liked his character as a kid way better than an adult. That's a huge complement on the child actor, or a slap in the face to Cube Gooding Jr. you decide.
Towards the middle of the movie Ricky has a chance to go to college. Ricky is a great character as well. He isn't so smart but he is good at football. He was another example of people wanting to get out of the hood and his only chance was football. This is the case for a lot of young people trapped in the gang life. Unfortunately, his story was more than predictable and half way through the movie I knew exactly how it was going to end. I wasn't surprised by the ending at all but it didn't take away from the movie as much as I thought it would. The very last scene with Tre and Ice Cube was so emotional and deep it saved the movie for me. It made me able to look past the predictability and enjoy the movie. 
Throughout this review I mention the thug life or the gangster life and I did not expect so much detail of the life in the movie. At one point there is a little girl in a diaper and Tre picks her up before a car hits her. Tre returns her to her mother and all the mother cares about is getting a fix. She didn't care about her child and wanted cocaine instead. "You selling rocks." She says. I know it's a movie but I believed that happens in real life and it made me sick. I like how Tre had a great relationship with his father. I expected him and his father to clash heads and argue, but they didn't. In more ways than one this movie surprised I liked it way more than I thought I would. 
Overall, Boyz 'N the Hood was very emotional, very impactful, very practicable, but very good and I can see myself watching it again and again. I can look past the obvious endgame and enjoy the cinematic experience. Ice Cube gave me a surprising performance while Cuba Gooding Jr. disappointed me. Lawrence Fishburne gave the best performance I have ever seen him in and I expected nothing less. With a title like Boyz 'N the Hood I expected the violent bloodbath. I did not expect the emotional rollercoaster and lovable and relatable characters. This movie surprised me a lot and I'm proud to give it the WillyT Honorable Mention.

Yup, I tell you what, nothing says quality, Oscar-nominated Cannes Film Festival entry quite like "Boyz n the Hood", featuring Ice Cube and Cuba Gooding, Jr., and directed by John Singletone before "2 Fast 2 Furious" and 2011's "Abduction", but make no mistake, if you can get by its title and soundtrack, this film good one. Hey, Laurence Fishburne's character in this film is named Furious, so maybe John Singleton did "2 Fast 2 Furious" because he thought he was being asked to do a sequel to this film, or at least that's my attempt at finding an excuse for Singleton's "2 Fast 2 Furious", because, you know, it makes Singleton's decision making sound much more sensible. Eh, whatever, I'm just going to go ahead and accept that it was only a matter of time, as Singleton has never been the most subtle of storytellers, as this film will actually tell you. I won't go so far as to deem this film's story concept minimalist, because this is a pretty juicy coming-of-age drama that needs time to develop, and takes that time, yet I'm not entirely sure a runtime that stops just short of two hours is entirely necessary, as reflected by the moments in which the film slips into excess material, if not filler, that does little more than run out the clock and slow down momentum, often into repetition. The film is by no means too repetitious, but it does have a tendency to fall into aimless spells that sometimes stick around so long that you kind of get used to them, thus making the eventual shifts in actual plotting focus slightly jarring, and therefore detrimental to resonance that is hurt enough by a bit of undeniable cheesiness. Sure, the film's dramatic hiccups are hardly the cheesiest moments in the film, because even when you disregard the lame '90s neo-soul/R&B and hip hop soundtrack, musical aspects are considerably hurt by a weakly corny score by Stanley Clarke that still carried the stink of pop film score sensibilities of the '80s, and yet, when cheesiness does catch up with the dramatic aspects, they're sometimes in the form of, of all things histrionics. I say, "of all things", because this film is generally quite genuine and realist in its handling of its worthy subject matter, yet there are still those occasions in which the film's dramatic kick feels kind of questionable, or at least comes off as questionable, because if nothing else is mishandled in this film, it is, of course, it's subtlety. There is enough inspiration behind the overdone dramatic touches to compensate for the resonance lost in the fierce wake of subtlety lapses, but there is no fully ignoring the blatant overemphasis on the intense themes and drama that drive this film, which would be more effective if it wasn't so desperate to be effective, telegraphing its depths in a passionately overambitious way that takes you out of the resonance a bit, no matter how striking it may be on the whole. The aforementioned flaws outside of subtlety issues range from barely considerable to fairly light, but subtlety issues can be enough to hold a drama back, and sure enough, no matter how much this film presses on as rewarding, its full potential is ironically all but lost because of John Singleton's being unable to be as controlled as he probably should be in the handling of a worthy tale. In spite of this, as overambitious as this film is, when it fulfills its ambition, at least to a certain degree, it compels, and let me tell you, this film fulfills hits such compelling moments more often than not, as well it should, considering the importance of its subject matter.

The conditions of darkly stereotypical black communities, or rather, "hoods", have been swiftly exacerbating for decades, with the early '90s timeframe in which this film takes place, alone, being all but beyond saving, and that's frustrating, especially when you look within the community and find what lucky few, relatively cleaner blacks there are being challenged, if not threatened, and even influenced by an inhumanly harsh environment that blemishes society as we know it, so the subject matter explored in this film is certainly relevant and important, with worthy that join drama potential within the story concept itself to craft a premise that deserves an inspired execution. As I said, the film is every bit as overambitious as it is inspired, and that cheeses up the interpretation of this worthy story concept, but make no mistake, for every aspect that is too ambitious for its own good, there is an aspect backed by genuinely effective inspiration, even in the writing department, as John Singleton puts together a script that isn't especially outstanding, but is rich enough to do this premise some justice, juggling so many themes - which include life in an unsafe environment, questionable influences, coming of age and bonds between loved ones - that it sometimes gets uneven in its thematic focus, but never to where the thematic depth and dramatic weight of this story aren't fleshed out enough to intrigue and compel. If Singleton accomplishes nothing else as screenwriter, he delivers on characterization that, in spite of subtlety issues and even the occasional histrionic beat, breathes enough life into the essence of this film's characters for them to feel relatable on a human level, and it helps that the portrayals of such well-rounded characters are also graced with human inspiration. As intense as plenty of this film's characters are in a lot of ways, there's only so much for this talented cast to work with, yet there's a certain charisma to everyone, and when more than just charisma is requested, the performers really deliver on dramatic heart whose gradual escalation helps in reinforcing a sense of escalation in the final product's intensity. The impassioned, if often rather underwritten performances throughout the final product help in driving the human weight to this layered and thematically rich study on important social themes, but at the end of the day, it's a certain offscreen performance that really brings Singleton's script to life, and that is, of course, Singleton himself. As director, Singleton doesn't so much unveil shortcomings to be fixed later, as much as he gives you tastes of shortcomings that he's always had, particularly when it comes to subtlety, because if Singleton were more restrained in his meditations upon this subject matter, we would perhaps be looking at a pretty powerful drama, yet as things stand, the commitment to Singleton's storytelling tends to compensate for many of the shortcomings in subtlety through striking imagery and soul that make the heavier moments tense and the more resonant moments all but, if not decidedly piercing. At the very least, Singleton entertains you enough to keep his flaws as a storyteller from throwing you off too much, and when such entertainment value is broken up by dramatic effectiveness, compellingness finds itself firmly secured enough for the final product to take all of its blows and still come out as effective.

Overall, filler often drives storytelling into aimless spells, while the occasional histrionic dramatic beat marks a particularly height in subtlety issues that taint the final product throughout its course and could have crafted an overambitiously underwhelming effort, yet goes fought back enough by the thematically heavy writing, inspired acting and generally entertaining, when not dramatically effective directorial storytelling to do a worthy story concept enough justice for "Boyz n the Hood" to stand as flawed, but ultimately compelling dramatic study on the deplorable then-modern and still-worsening conditions of inner city black communities.
